content:
ber 18, 2015
												Awesome game. See that large number on the time played above? Yeah that has only been since it got on Steam. Yes the graphics are dated and some of the base D&D mechanics are creaking under the weight of all the add-ons done over the years. Most of the problems with mechanics tend to show up at the upper level ranges (20+) Many of the recent adjustments to classes has taken some of the difficulty edge off of the lower levels as power creep has reared its head. -----------For the absolute best DDO experience:get 3-4-5 friends that have zero experience playing. Have everyone go through the tutorial (it is solo only). Set up a schedule of play time and request that no one plays at all outside of the group time, no spoilers!Dont go read about how best to play the game or the best builds , etc. The exploration and learning on your own when it is all fresh to the whole crew is priceless. Some dungeons have you thinking with your fighter ,barbarian or sorcerer you are the baddest MoFo ever. Next dungeon you are cheering on the rogue who is sneaking around a room full of big, bad Ogres, that would squash him in no time flat if they see him/her, picking up the soul stones(dead PCs) of the entire party to take them back to the shrine to be raised from the dead. ===========================Lots to do as free to play so no need to pull out the CC right away. If you follow the above plan for best experience by time you get to where you feel the 'need' to pay, you will gladly be screaming "take my money, now!" -----------------------One word of caution about making characters;Many of the older dungeons have the unfortunate MMO min/maxer design problem. You will run in to somethings that require X Strength score to open or Y skill points to trick an NPC will seem really high. The desiginers couldn't make the stat requirements too low where a balanced character could complete with out making things trivial for the min/maxers.Just keep that in mind when building that maxing or nearly maxing your primary ability scores is suggested and likewise it is better to have a few skills that are maxed rather than a bunch of skills with low investment. ~~~~~~~~

content:
, 2016
												DDO is a mmo co-op dungeon crawler. It uses a hub system with various "dungeons" attached. These usually have a set of objectives that needs to be completed, which is hardly ever "kill 20 monsters". In this way, the game becomes quite different from most other MMO's. A pro and con, is that the game has almost unlimited character customization possibilities and in my opinion no clear, or dominating, "meta" besides potential flavour of the month. I have never been restricted from joining a group for playing an unorthodox build. The character customization can make it complex when starting out, but also fun (or self-torturing) as there are many things to try. Generally DDO has a very friendly community. If you are playing a few hours everyday, then doing your time playing/leveling you will certainly meet the same people more than once.  I am in a love/hate relationship with the controls. At times they feel clunky. But depending on class and playstyle you can easily avoid the otherwise standard "Tab-Target stand-still spell-cast-time" combat style of other MMO's. I suggest you don't get too adventurous with your first character, or those controls might give you a "Morrowind-like" combat. DDO is largely numbers-based. (But but! It can be fun to make your own custom character, don't be afraid! ;))If you want something premade, then I suggest googling "DDO build repository". That post might be gone or old by the time you read this, then you should ask for build advice in the new player section of the forums. As I said, the game has a friendly community. Whatever you do, avoid the pre-set class builds when creating your character. They are old and nobody uses them for good reason.Two questions I usually see on forums: - Are people still playing this game? Yes. The player-base on the servers are quite similar, except Wayfinder. Avoid Wayfinder.- Is the game Pay to Win? Or let me rephrase: Can Free to play get along? Short answer: Yes. Semi-long: New player builds (see repository) can be made to handle themselves, spend earned in-game currency on adventure packs, and consider spending any minimum amount of real life money on the game to make your account status to premium.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
1, 2015
												40 hours on Steam + at least 3,000 in its own launcher.The goods:This game has loads of great aspects to it, ranging from group questing to a 'True Reincarnation' mechanic allowing for endless play.The party questing allows for some easier playthroughs of the harder quests in the game at low levels and even when you hit the heroic level cap. Each player gets their own loot from chests which can be switched around and given to others via the chest's item drop-down menu allowing for some Bound to Account/Character items to be traded before they're claimed.The leveling system in this game is real easy to learn but very complex and detailed when you truely understand it allowing for pretty much any combination of classes that don't clash to work. There are thousands of custom player-made builds to try on the forums which give you an edge over a standard build. Being able to combine up to 3 classes will also give you an edge too. Want to play as a caster but still be able to disable traps? No problem! Combine Wizard and Rogue for the easiest of them all.The True Reincarnation mechanic of this game allows for endless play, as once you hit the heroic level cap of 20 you unlock the ability to remake your character with benefits. You gain +4 points for your build from Adventurer to Hero, +2 from Hero to Legend and it caps at 36. Champion characters will only gain a +2 stat boost going into Hero as they already start at 32 points. Each time you True Reincarnate (TR), you gain extra abilities based on your previous life. For example, if you were a Barbarian in your last life, you gain 10 HP. All passive past life feats stack up to 3 times. Also, you can take an 'Active' past life feat which allows for extra boosts ingame such as Barbarian's 'Berserker's fury' past life feat allowing you to use a Rage like ability in which a Barbarian has as a different class.Heroic and Epic levels are a fairly new feature of DDO which has only really come around in the past few years and is still massively developing. Now the level cap has been raised to 28 allowing for more Feats and Stats to be gained, giving an even greater advantage over your enemies in quests. With this came a new item system that has 4 different tiers of loot for Heroic and Epic quests. These items are paired with the difficulty they were looted in, giving boosts greater if the difficulty was too.This is an EXCELLENT F2P game as you NEVER have to buy anything in the game if you decide you don't want to, as you get 'Favor' for completing quests which in turn grants you 'Turbine Points' to spend in the store.The bads:DDO has a lot of flaws in its own right, but none more than your average MMORPG. It's always going to have bugs which the community are always trying to stamp out through the use of the public beta test client, Lamannia.DDO IS a pay2win game. You'll never get to level 28 at the current state of the game unless you get some of the epic-level addon content.Summary:Although there may seem more good points than bad, you'll find a lot more yourself from just playing in both aspects. Each person has their own preference of games and whats in them and I love DDO because it's a group-based game. You'll find it much easier to complete quests and objectives if you team up with 5 other people. DDO is an ever-expanding game which is currently on its 25th major update excluding patches for bugs. I could write an essay that makes A Song of Ice and Fire look small and easy to read on whats great and what sucks about the game, but nobody would want to read it. I'd be surprised if people actually read this far into my review. Anyway, going off on a tangent, the game is amazing if you like to team up with friends to go on an epic adventure through the levels, facing different enemies on the way from slimy, annoying ooze monsters that love to break your weapons to Acid-breathing dragons and much more.I'd give this game a rating of 7.5 out of 10, as it still has a long way to go to be able to catch up with the major MMOs such as Guild Wars 2 and World of Warcraft. On the other hand, it holds its own playstyle I've yet to see in any other MMO of group-based questing from the start.If you do decide to play the game, Cannith is a great server! Thousands of players always willing to help you, all you need to do is ask. Just remember, asking around for help in the starter area won't get you far, you have to venture out into the world.Hope to see you in-game soon! ^_^

y 6, 2016
												This game used to be fun back in Mod 8, Now it is at Mod 9 Update 30.Also, know that I play as a VIP and have all expansions packsYou will need to understand D&D machanics to understand my review (not DDO mechanics)When they added the Mod 9, it was a nice change because of True Reincarnation and you could reach level 20.Of course, the bad part was the free to play. The problem comes with the fact that you do not have access to every content. So with the already small population, it makes teaming harder. (The tool to find a group though is the best).I just started back at Mod 9 Update 29 and played few weeks and got really disapointed. The core mechanics of Dungeon and Dragon are no longer present. There is no longer the rule of 1d20 + attack bonus >= Armor Class. That was a simple rule and easy to understand.Also now, monsters have ridiculours hp. More than 500 hp for normal mobs is not normal at level 14. For a boss once in a while ok, but really, its gotten out of hand. I prefered before when they had a good AC with a lot less hp.There is also the guild airship. They can give you buffs, but now there is just too many that you dont care anymore (30+).Also, even though enhancements (kind of feats) is fun (I used to love it because it adds some customization to the character) it became more powerful than taking a feat. It was really something when you actually take a feat (in most cases you have 7 to choose (for a level 20 char)). You have access to 80 enhancement points and for 1 point, you get 2 AC, etc.2 AC is what you would get with an epic level feat (21+), not a level 1 character.The more they update the game, the more they stray from the real dungeon and dragon.While it still can be a fun game (I did not bother listing the positive and obvious negative such as the outdated graphics), it is shadowed by bad decisions by making it a greedy generic MMO that you would find anywhere.

y 1, 2015
												Bottom line (at the top): It's ok, I'd recommend it because I enjoy it, but you need to be able to see through the WoW-ification of a decent D&D game.I've got mixed feelings about this game, perhaps that's why I keep coming back to it. Essentially what happens is every 2 or 3 months Turbine releases an update that either completely alters the gameplay experience or breaks 3 or 4 old quests (or both), and they slowly hotfix about 50-75% of it (I've seen a Level 2 quest that's been around since before I started playing being unavailable for an ENTIRE update period!), and then they release a new update. As for gameplay, it's ok as far as D&D-based TPHSMMORPGS's go. Lack of proper support and lousy management decisions aside, the community is good, the fanbase is awesome and there's something to do for every non-epic level (1-20) without having to pay for anything.If you like D&D-based games that have gone off-track a little (think in the direction of WoW), this may be the time sink you need. Otherwise, there's tons of other (more populated) MMO's that might suit your fancy.

												I enjoyed this game for 4 years. I loved its combat system, instanced dungeons and social focus.However, the game has taken a turn for the worst. tl;dr Money is basically irrelevant unless you have a lot of it. Difficulty is meaningless. Either you can solo elite or your build isn't viable. Difficulty takes the form of giving the mobs more stats instead of actual meaningful difficulty. Pros:- Fun for groups.- Innovative true reincarnation system.- Multiclassing and build planning is fun.- Still updating.Neutral:- Grindy but not bad. If you know how to do the dungeon, it takes 3-10 minutes to complete it and you normally do it 3/5 times minimum, 10 times maximum.- True reincarnation adds to the grind.Cons:- Might as well be a subscription game. You hit a brick wall at level 14 unless you're spending money. Or grinding for favor.- Very strict definition of what is viable, especially in the newer dungeons and at high level.- It's a dying game. Hard to find groups if you're not at the high levels.- Not recommended unless you have a premade group that plays regularly.- Regularly bugged. Not too intrusive, but not recommended if you don't have patience.- Updates aren't fixing the problem.

												I have to say this is my favorite MMO of all time. I have played off and on since 2006. The game is just different from other MMOs. The dungeons and combat have a way of making you feel like you are in the world. Trapped down in a dungeon. At times you will find yourself just barely getting through a dungeon. The best way to enjoy this game in my opinion is to get a small group of friends (2-6). Even if it's just two of you. Only play the game together if possible, and only run dungeons on elite. The joy of experiencing a fresh dungeon with a few friends, and not knowing what is around the corner is much of what this game has to offer. That feeling of getting one shot by a trap is beyond anything I have seen in a MMO. The game suffers from a few balance issues, but it's acceptable given the amount of customization it has to offer. The microtransactions are fair. I would say just get a sub and everything else is pretty unnecessary. It’s always fun to come back  to DDO and run some dungeons with friends.

content:
ry 21
												I've played allot of MMOs, and this is my favorite by far [I even like it more than my first MMO, which I played for 4+ years and still love]. Not because it's D&D; I don't care about that. DDO has the most complex, demanding, and rewarding game mechanics I've seen - by far. The dungeons are carefully crafted to [on the hardest settings, which you can control completely when subscribed] require intense strategizing: if you screw around for a second, if you don't think your way through every moment, you will fail. But, when you learn the system, and set the difficulty correctly, it's also completely fair.The dungeons provide an extremely wide variety of carefully crafted strategic situations, and regularly surprises you as everything suddenly spirals out of control due to intentionally placed surprises - this, however, becomes a nonexistent factor once you've played through them once [changing trap locations aside]. The intitial dungeons [levels 1-3] aren't a great example of my claims, especially on F2P, since you won't be able to increase the difficulty to the hardest settings without first playing through the easier [normal, hard, elite] settings. But, give it time. The game is also stellar for team-play: every class has dramatic strengths over other classes, which when combined, make your team that much more powerful.Though I personally consider this game to be, mechanically, decades ahead of all other titles, it has many flaws. Though the mechanics are extremely complex and fair [both the character building system, and combat], the game nevertheless has a wide variety of minor yet annoying bugs. Game-breaking? No; if we exclude the atrocious hireling AI. I don't recall ever being deep in a brutal dungeon and losing because of a bug. Nevertheless, you'll just have to get used to issues which have always existed on this old engine. Nothing to be done about it. And while the mechanics function correctly, and are precisely fair, there are a wide variety of issues when it comes to understanding them: there is very little explanation of how many of the mechanics work [even ddowiki, which is your best source of information, has blindspots], so you'll be spending allot of time researching from multiple sources. For example: If you want to multiclass, which opens an extremely wide variety of game-play styles, there's very little information ingame about it - even simply sticking to one class can be a very complicated process. And, ontop of all that, many tooltips for spells and skills are incomplete or blatantly inaccurate.  Another issue to keep in mind is that the game can be a serious money-pit, even when carrying a subscription: there are numerous convenience upgrades which can only be bought with real money. Though many of those upgrades can be earned ingame through simply playing, are available as long as subscribed, and a subscription includes currency which can be spent toward those upgrades.All that aside, when deciding whether or not to commit, keep in mind that I have understated the complexity of the system, and that you will have to learn a great deal if you want to play on the level of difficulty which I love. Also that, to be completely blunt, you will need to play with at least 2 total people - ideally 3 or more, if you want to get the most out of the game. Though you can simply turn down the dungeon difficulty, and use "hirelings" for most situations while soloing, there are nevertheless many which demand specific classes and multiple people. There are plenty of player groups [guilds] to join. In total: If you're the hardest-core strategist, if you love extremely tight team-play, this is the absolute best option for you - though remember that you need to carefully calibrate the difficulty settings, and your second playthrough of a dungeon will remove the surprises. Still, it's a flawed masterpeice; you will have to take the bad with the good.To whomever was in charge of building this game's mechanics: I consider myself in your debt, for the joys you've granted me. I appreciate and understand the intense mastery you possess and hope you are given your due.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2013
												Of all of the MMOs I've played, Dungeons & Dragons Online is not only the most fun, but the most addicting out of all of them. The difficulty of learning how the game works (menus, hotkeys, rules, etc...) is not too overbearing on first-time players and can be picked up very quickly. Games such as STO (Star Trek Online), while also being a great MMO, have a much steeper learning curve when it comes to the interface, knowing where to go or how to do something is much more difficult and takes a longer time, like many other MMOs. There are some picky things about DDO, and some would agree or disagree, everyone is entitled to how they think MMOs should play. However, DDO doesn't have "grinding" or any monotonous quests. Every single one is unique and exciting. A very BALANCED (being that it IS Dungeon & Dragons) party is definitely recommended for later quests in the game. As frustrating as that sounds, I'll counter that with the fact that it is incredibly fun having a defined role in a party (Healer, DPS, Trapper, Tank, etc....) and that not many MMOs (if any at all) have that sort of specific role-placement. If there ARE any, I can guarentee that it's nowhere as refined as DDO. The leveling system IS slow, because you rank up 4 times before actually gaining a level. That being said, it gives you a huge sense of accomplishment when you DO level up, every race and class are so unique that when you level up you feel like you're creating your own unique character that no one has ever done. A huge helper is that the game is FTP, although if you get addicted enough, you WILL end up spending money. I recommend this game, and since it's FTP, there is nothing to lose. I hope this recommendation helps your decision, whoever you may be.

												In my honest opinion, this is by far the best MMO I have ever had the fortune to experience. Unparalleled dungeoning experience with traps, obstacles, relatively varied landscapes, excellent voice acting and narration, and engaging combat that feels like more than merely target and hit 1, 2, 3. All around the game has a very immersive feel to it. All classes have a use, most of which have a unique/different style of playing. Most dungeons require a team effort, and a varied one at that. Can absolutely play solo, if thats your thing, with the introduction of NPC Helper's (basically you buy a mercenary contract to assist you in dungeons). Rogues can dps, but they mostly act as trap/obstacle disablers and hidden location scouts, and are thus about equally sought after for party composition as a healer would be.

You can increase the difficulty (and rewards) with additional people.+instances mean no kill stealing or reward hogging,  so much better than open-world click-fests.+omg, the character building.  there's so much fun to be had putting together a character of 10+ races and 12 classes, and you can mix up to 3 classes on each character. 												Overall, I give this game a thumbs up.  The game has been around a while and has an established community.  There is plenty of content.  As a dungeons and dragons game, it has several races and classes to choose from and at each level you can choose class and skills, similar to the 3rd edition(s) of dungeons and dragons.  I found the gameplay smooth and controls easy to use.  Quests were entertaining and I liked exlporing the city.  The quests are all instanced so you don't have to compete, though you can take a party of adventurers. When my friends weren't available, I found content that I could manage by myself or with one of the game's hirelings (AI helper).  There is some content that you don't get with the free to play - extra races, some dungeon areas, and a few classes - but there is still plenty of content to keep you interested all the way to highest levels.  I do note that PVP was very limited - only in special arenas in the taverns (bar fights).  Graphics are excellent.  As expected in D&D, there are tons of spells, equipment, monster types, etc.  Stealth and lockpicking are included and work well.

content:
28, 2015
												It is difficult to decide how to rate DDO. On one hand is it' s downsides; including (but not limited to) expencive VIP sub, limited F2P options (starts really limiting you at level 8) and very slow turbine point gain for F2P players, limiting their ability to  purchace adventures. However, for those willing to pay for all the things that would need paying for, it is a jolly old time indeed. It is, by far, the best MMORPG created this side of Ultima online and Wurm. Seriously, the combat is the best I have ever experienced in any MMO ever. The dungeons are instanced: no more fetch 100 slimes or kill 50 goblins! Quests are all interesting and never a bore. Quests could range from having you go through an onslaught of foes to defeat the final boss to having you destroy crates while being unable to kill a certain type of monster. The game follows the lore of DDO very well. There is a HUGE amount of freedom in character creation. However, the business practices of WB and turbine are... questionable. The DLC packs are expencive, and you will find yourself paying for adventures because the subscription is so expencive. Even then, subscribers don't have all the content. You must still pay for stuff. All in all, I recommend this game ONLY IF  YOU ARE WILLING TO PAY SOMETHING. Buying something with real money unlocks character slots and favor growth (which is used to gain rep with factions and get free stuff like races and classes).

content:
er 8, 2016
												background: I was a Founder for this game 1 week prior to release, name on game landmark. Over the years I have loved and played this game from its inception, however things changed for the worst. Likes: The main draw for me was quests, how it played, and the friendly nature of making new charecters and playing them to a moderate fruition. Then try a different build. Social tavern settings (now faded away) was nice after adventuring. The game was smaller more managable and really spoke to the entire DnD model of creating and playing any kind of charecter you wanted in a game enviroment for all ages and what build next excitment. Over the years the way quests were delivered or updated in old areas of town worked well and made breaks from the game a pleasent suprise without it being a daunting task of catch up.Dislikes/destroyed the game:More updates/modules were great but there comes a point when any game reaches too much content and too excessive for its own good. Sadly, DDO reached that some time ago. There now is too much content making it impossible to get steady groups anymore or enjoy the content that worked and made it what it was. Now its a zerg fest to get past all the old content and spend hours soloing and/or farming  for what exactly? midgame and endgame changed.... all that endgame farming, which is why this games great gouping is now a shallow hole of failure. Ingame market? uh,  lets not go there...... That whole "free to play" model saved this game a time ago,I am saddened at the state the game is now but watching the games progression over the years is nice. It all comes down to money, free to play saved DDO but the desire to "sell it" and pump it full of bloated content severly impacted the game(example auction house and currency). Endgame content is good and there were good additions but you loose some things, steady grps ALL the time for everything and the comfortable DnD atmosphere where groups or people congregated in-game, changing these things alienate and deminish its original art upon release. Now its barren grouping, over content thinning out what the game was. Excessive content and change after change is killing modern gaming, imo. You wouldnt ask "Picaso" to rework his masterpieces over and over, why do video game artforms have to be changed and molded until there is nothing but a shell of former glory. Theres something to be said about going out on your best leg.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 1, 2015
												Verdict: RECOMMENDEDBefore we get into this review, I have at least over 3000+ hours on this game, I have been playing it for 7 years I don't use the Steam version often. Oh and hey to anyone who knows Gonnakillu, Scottyj and my 17 other toons from Argonneson (add me if you do <3)The actual combat system is definitely one of the best I have used in MMO's I have played my fair share of MMO's and in my opinion the combat system/engine in this game tops all of them, for a game that was released in 2006 (I think) it has a really advanced combat system and I would call it advanced for games today.To actually have fun with this game you do not even have to have friends playing with you as there is a great group engine which allows everyone around the world to be connected together and play with eachother, you can mark yourself as LFG (Looking For Group). The game is also fun while soloing through quests but you can also have support from hirelings, which is an friendly AI which you purchase to hire for an hour (time doesn't go on whilst not in quests/wildernesses). Speaking of the AI's, although they are sterotyped to be stupid as a pinecone they are actually very useful to have at times and they're very well developed.For classes/races there are so many options to pick, I think there are a total of 14 classes, but that can change at anytime because Turbine are always updating the game with new classes/races, I also think there is a total of 14 races now that they've added in Gnomes, unforunately I haven't been on to see this yet. The race you pick can also effect your class stability and changes your stats such as Charisma, Wisdom, Strength, for example a Halfling will have decreased Strength and a Drow will have decreased Intelligence, this is also a very good system that stops very over powered builds coming in game.The servers itself are very good, I do not ever experience lag, whenever I do it is on my end, there are not many maintenances that occur.The game is F2P but after a certain level lets say, 12 it is very hard to progress without some adventure packs and you will find yourself grinding the same quest a lot, VIP is quite cheap for a monthly subscription, but you can also just buy the adventure packs individually and in your own time. If you are P2P'ing you will have a better time with the game as you will not have to ransack every F2P quest out there as a lot of adventure packs are added frequently that you will have access to once released (as a VIP) You can also either the races/classes or get them for free with VIP, but you can also earn the in-game without implementing a single penny into the game via favor which you earn with every quest you complete, the amount of favor points you get is increased if you do the quest on a higher difficulty (please note there is a lot of F2P classes/races but there is a lot of P2P classes/races as well).This game can also be used to make a lot of friends which could lead you into a high level guild which makes the whole experience a lot better and more fun. Your guild you have joined or created can also get an airship, you may unlock the first airship at level 20 (guild level) I believe and you will start to unlock better airships gradually when you increase your guild level, these airships can be brought by in game currency (platinum, gold, silver, cooper etc) or Turbine Points. These airships aren't just there for design though, they are able to have buffs on then which increase your stats which are very useful especially when going on high level raids.The PvP feature is outstanding, I guilty enough, have spent most of my hours in the PvP areas which are normally located in taverns, the most populated one being the Wayward Lobster in Harbor. Although in my server it isn't as populated as it used to be once be (the good ol' days :'( ) it is still a fun feature which you can mess around with friends with, there are also game modes such as capture the flag and all of that shenanigans but I am not sure if it is working shape as I haven't heard of it for a while.The character creation is an extraodinary engine, it has many options to pick with which can be used ot make a already built build (highly recommended for new players) or a custom build which you can decide where your points go and what spells you decide on. You can even choose your own aliginment (not sure if spelt right) In the past couple of years they've implemented a lot of good features such as new skill trees, epic feats, epic destinies etc and this has changed the game a lot as there is so much more to do. This game, in my opinion, has the best charactor creation engine out there.If you decide to buy VIP right off the hook make sure you DO NOT start an iconic character straight away as this will take you to level 15 and as a newbie you will be absolutely crushed in quests (that is if you know how to get to quests by that point) make sure you try one of the beginner classes and start off slow and get the drift of the game first, get a character to level 1-15 instead of skipping the levels.An outstanding feature is True Reincarnation which can be used at level 20 to set you back to level 1 but it will be like you are creating a whole new character as you can pick a whole new race and class but it will be a lot more stronger, powerful and it will give you a lot more options, if you true reincarnate again you will be stronger and more powerful than your 2nd life, after your 3rd life you will have one more boost your points you can add onto your stats etc until it will stay the same and if you do one life on every class you will get a feat that will stick onto you forever called "Completionist" this drasticlly improves your stats etc,  although this will take a lot years to do, I know a few people myself who has done it, I myself have a family member who has done it.The community in the game is great, but they're also some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ on there, but hey this is the Internet it is a normal occurance, most of the community are completely chilled and good people and are willing to be your friend have group with you to complete quests together and the community 9/10 helps you out, hey, I had someone give me 100k plat to my brother who was starting out at the time.I will probably add more to this tomorrowOh and Turbine, update your steam homepage and use it more and fix the purchases on steam, anyone who thinks they are going to purchase in game do not download on steam as it is broken, download here https://signup.ddo.com/ddo.php?ftui=DDOBlackDragon&abrs=100_1457230160

content:
19, 2015
												This game has 1 major flaw; it's really gosh darn hard to get into, I really cannot remember how I managed to trawl through the uninteresting mess that are the low levels and starter zone, but I certainly do not regret it; this game is so amazingly unique and I love it <3Now this game is technically an MMORPG, and MMORPGs have a great level of stigmatism, mostly caused by great numbers of Korean WoW-clone grind fest chatboxes. DDO isn't like that, DDO is focused on the 'game' part; character building (my personal favourite part, just like real DnD) and play-style are very important, so if you want an MMO with unique and interesting gameplay, give DDO a try.However, this gameplay focus came at a remarkable cost; the social aspect, every quest is an instance, which while making them unique, means you can't just party up with people half-way and make friends easy; you have to make groups beforehand and go into the dungeon together. Of course the Devs don't expect us to do that all by ourselves, so there is a "Grouping" menu, where people can put out server-wide messages to find people to quest with; and it works well enough. But- the DDO community has gained a very... "elitist" edge to it over time, and try as I might, I am not exempt to this rule; many in-game factors make it hard not to become rather "elitist", per se, over time. Many people are interested only in speed running dungeons for optimal xp, and have little-to-no-interest in making friends. This can make things very hard for newer players, who want to take it slow, learn the rather complex mechanics, and make some friends.All in all, I love DDO and would love to see it thrive, but until the Devs overhaul the starter area, early levels and social aspect, (I say this, I have no idea what they could do to spice them up though :/), I can only really recommed DDO to groups - at least 2 people (max party size is 6) - who are looking for a group based, challenging PvE RPG that rewards effort and planning.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Alright, my history with this game is rather dubious. For the last few years now, since around 2010, this game has been on my Steam account collecting dust, and is the standard nostalgic game that you have on the shelf that you haven't played in years. So you walk into your bedroom, bored out of your mind, and you ask yourself what you're going to do to pass the time; that's when you see this game sitting on the shelf. You're wide-eyed, surprised to see it, and instantly grab the dusty game case and look at it with nostalgic visions of how much fun you had with it. However, about six hours of gameplay and perhaps a few days off and on with the game, you begin to realize why it was collecting dust on your shelf, and you kind of want to put it back where it was.Dungeons & Dragons Online is an amazing FTPMMO, don't get me wrong, but it's flawed; oh boy is it flawed. As a massive Dungeons & Dragons fan/player, I jumped onboard when I found out about this game and signed up and started playing, only to find true horrors to await for me. Combat is all over the place with various degrees of difficulty for more hauls of loot and experience for your character, the quests themselves are simple fetch-quests or the standard "kick in the door" style of game in which you saunter over to an Orc's cozy cottage, kick in its door and then brutally slaughter it and its family. There isn't really a whole level of role-playing IN the game, it's a hack and slash MMO and the players are forced to role-play with their friends to gain a better experience.Now the two grated problems with this game, wait, THREE problems are as followed: Character Creation, Character Development, and Character Interaction. Right out of the gate as a player, you're instantly penalized in the character creator with having incredibly low stats and penalizing you if you're not a paying member for Turbine. With that, you're tossed out onto the sandy beaches of Korthos Island with a poor chance of holding your own against the enemies that await you in the Hard and Elite difficulties, unless you min/max your character mainly into a Cleric, Fighter, Paladin, or Monk (which is a member class). Character development is also lacking greatly in this game, due to its constraints as a video game, let alone an MMO. In the actual pen and paper version of the game, your character has an immense amount of space to develop into whatever version of the class you choose to be. Want to be a wizard that specializes in certain spells and feats to optimize said spells? Can't do that in DDO. Want to become a minion summoning spellcaster that can command a multitude of summoned creatures to defend you and do as you will? Can't do that in DDO. You're given three to four skill trees, depending on your character's class, and race, which you put Action Points (AP) into to gain a variety of bonus abilities and traits to aid you within the game. However, while this on paper or in my review may sound like an amazing concept, in practice, the abilities are very subpar and don't really mesh well with the game. On several occasions, the special attacks or perks just seemed lackluster and a waste of my Action Points, and at times, I even questioned if they were better than basic attacks.Character interaction may be the biggest glaring obstacle in this game for me. Guilds, adventuring parties, and raid groups are the main defacto groups for players to interact with each other, and are the vanilla concept for any MMORPG. I get it, MMO's nowadays need to catch up to World of Warcraft's template and show that they're hip and cool, but when it comes to Dungeons & Dragons, the grandaddy of the entire role-playing game genre, you should show some more respect. Every player is required to join a party to do several questlines, even if they have started the first three quests and are on the final homestretch of the adventure, as well as being incredibly handicapped when it comes to not being in a guild with people they do not know. The way the game ropes players in to joining said guilds are with benefits such as cheaper healing prices, and low-level gear is now cheaper, however, the only way to obtain such perks is to spam other players invitations to those guilds. You see, the way guilds progress in the game, is by member count; the higher the count, the more perks unlocked. This means that a player exiting the boat from the tutorial region, is almost assailed by fledgling guilds and end-game guilds who want that finally person in their roster to get the perk they've been dying to obtain and that is just wrong. For the last 180 hours clocked in over four years, the only time I actually discussed anything in the chat with other people, were the few friends I had who enjoyed or were anxious to join me on Dungeons & Dragons Online and those times were few and far between. All in all, and with a heavy and decisive "no", I've got to give this game a 4.5/5 out of 10.

content:
15, 2015
												By far the best blending of D&D 3.5 rules with an MMO feel.  While it may take some getting used to, once you grasp the basics, it'll click quite nicely.This is set in the Eberron world for the most part, not the Forgotten Realms of major fame but don't let that stop you.  The Eberron setting is unique and a lot of fun.There are several classes available for you to select right from the start, and your four "basic" D&D races, Humans, Dwarves, Elves and Halflings.  And while each race does have a certain feel and flavor about them, as with proper D&D, you are free to combine whatever class you can with whatever race you can.That said, there are some classes and races that can only be unlocked via Cash Shop.  Or you can get a subscription.  Due note, not all classes are unlocked with a subscription, and they are unlocked only for the subscription.  Best to just buy them outright.Yes, there's a lot of slow going for this game, you don't just rush to the end.  But when you do get there, you can "reset" your character, causing them to be revived at low level, but with an extra stat points on your build, which lets you make an even more powerful character.If you're looking for a D&D game that'll get you hip-deep in the mechancis of it, this is the game for you.  If you're looking for something more MMO and modern, look into Neverwinter, which is based on the 4th edition rules.

For the last few years now, since around 2010, this game has been on my Steam account collecting dust, and is the standard nostalgic game that you have on the shelf that you haven't played in years. So you walk into your bedroom, bored out of your mind, and you ask yourself what you're going to do to pass the time; that's when you see this game sitting on the shelf. You're wide-eyed, surprised to see it, and instantly grab the dusty game case and look at it with nostalgic visions of how much fun you had with it. However, about six hours of gameplay and perhaps a few days off and on with the game, you begin to realize why it was collecting dust on your shelf, and you kind of want to put it back where it was.Dungeons & Dragons Online is an amazing FTPMMO, don't get me wrong, but it's flawed; oh boy is it flawed. As a massive Dungeons & Dragons fan/player, I jumped onboard when I found out about this game and signed up and started playing, only to find true horrors to await for me. Combat is all over the place with various degrees of difficulty for more hauls of loot and experience for your character, the quests themselves are simple fetch-quests or the standard "kick in the door" style of game in which you saunter over to an Orc's cozy cottage, kick in its door and then brutally slaughter it and its family. There isn't really a whole level of role-playing IN the game, it's a hack and slash MMO and the players are forced to role-play with their friends to gain a better experience.Now the two grated problems with this game, wait, THREE problems are as followed: Character Creation, Character Development, and Character Interaction. Right out of the gate as a player, you're instantly penalized in the character creator with having incredibly low stats and penalizing you if you're not a paying member for Turbine. With that, you're tossed out onto the sandy beaches of Korthos Island with a poor chance of holding your own against the enemies that await you in the Hard and Elite difficulties, unless you min/max your character mainly into a Cleric, Fighter, Paladin, or Monk (which is a member class). Character development is also lacking greatly in this game, due to its constraints as a video game, let alone an MMO. In the actual pen and paper version of the game, your character has an immense amount of space to develop into whatever version of the class you choose to be. Want to be a wizard that specializes in certain spells and feats to optimize said spells? Can't do that in DDO. Want to become a minion summoning spellcaster that can command a multitude of summoned creatures to defend you and do as you will? Can't do that in DDO. You're given three to four skill trees, depending on your character's class, and race, which you put Action Points (AP) into to gain a variety of bonus abilities and traits to aid you within the game. However, while this on paper or in my review may sound like an amazing concept, in practice, the abilities are very subpar and don't really mesh well with the game. On several occasions, the special attacks or perks just seemed lackluster and a waste of my Action Points, and at times, I even questioned if they were better than basic attacks.Character interaction may be the biggest glaring obstacle in this game for me. Guilds, adventuring parties, and raid groups are the main defacto groups for players to interact with each other, and are the vanilla concept for any MMORPG. I get it, MMO's nowadays need to catch up to World of Warcraft's template and show that they're hip and cool, but when it comes to Dungeons & Dragons, the grandaddy of the entire role-playing game genre, you should show some more respect. Every player is required to join a party to do several questlines, even if they have started the first three quests and are on the final homestretch of the adventure, as well as being incredibly handicapped when it comes to not being in a guild with people they do not know. The way the game ropes players in to joining said guilds are with benefits such as cheaper healing prices, and low-level gear is now cheaper, however, the only way to obtain such perks is to spam other players invitations to those guilds. You see, the way guilds progress in the game, is by member count; the higher the count, the more perks unlocked. This means that a player exiting the boat from the tutorial region, is almost assailed by fledgling guilds and end-game guilds who want that finally person in their roster to get the perk they've been dying to obtain and that is just wrong. For the last 180 hours clocked in over four years, the only time I actually discussed anything in the chat with other people, were the few friends I had who enjoyed or were anxious to join me on Dungeons & Dragons Online and those times were few and far between. All in all, and with a heavy and decisive "no", I've got to give this game a 4.5/5 out of 10.

												Many a long night has been spent in a dark basement, rolling the forbidden polyhedral die and casting spells that no one in the mortal world could even dream of. Harsh landscapes have been traversed and deep dungeons have been explored by those dreamed of living in another world and embarking on untold of adventure. Those were the days when such basement meetings were widely frowned upon, and those who partook in the art of Dungeons and Dragons were widely shunned or treated as pariahs. Does anyone remember the great Tom Hanks scare? What about the ridiculous ‘Dark Dungeons’ Chick tract that led many to believe D&D was nothing more than a tool of the devil?Those days have long passed and the mystery of Dungeons and Dragons has passed into legend. These days tabletop gamers meet in the open, exploring dungeons with friends and strangers alike. Lately, however(as of the last fifteen years), the RPG genre has moved online, and as a result, the game has changed entirely. You can only imagine the happiness and joy expressed by old school gamers when Dungeons and Dragons Online was released in February of 2006, even with a subscription fee. Now that the game has gone free to play, players around the world have been given the opportunity to experience Eberron in all its tinkered glory.

												I won't sugar-coat this.This game is dated as all hell, and it shows mostly in the graphics department. Beyond this little bit, the game is VERY fun, can be incredibly challenging (scaling difficulty), and is in my top 5 favorite games of all time.It's based around 3.5 rules in terms of character creation, but apart from only being able to multiclass into 3 total classes, the character levelling process is staggeringly varied, and the best part is that most builds will work to some degree, whether it be a niche setup, a full out min-maxed badass, or some fun little generalist you enjoy tinkering around with. You might not be clearing Epic Elite Reaper 5 difficulty quests on everything, but there's many settigns you can try, as well as solo/group support on every quest and dungeon.If you've got some spare time and are looking for something MMO-based, but still want the ability to explore on your own, give this game a shot. It's free to start, and you can unlock most game content withuot spending a penny. Some things are gated by Micro-Transactions, but they aren't required to enjoy the game, and merely add more options and more flavor to an already packed game.

content:
er 16, 2016
												Obviously the game is not for everyone, but I mainly want to say the mixed reviews represent half the people hating it and the other half loving it to the death.  DDO isn't the newest or most visually flashy game out there (not that it's bad visually, it's great, but just not the latest, greatest graphics) - and yet, there are still people who avidly play this game ten years plus and still going.Personally, I'm an orginal D&D player from back when the game was printed on freakin' pamphlets and handed out to college students - before even the red box og's refer to.  I've also tried every damn D&D online game in existence.  I find most of them either feel like I'm playing some kind of anime manga thing . . . or they're very cartoonish and feature click bar buttons that launch complex attack combos that can be chained together . . .  or they feel like Diablo.  Those are all great in their own way - but they're not Dungeons and Dragons as I know it.  Hell, Neverwinter Online, which also bears the D&D trademark is not Dungeons and Dragons as I know it.DDO is the closest thing I've found to playing a video game version of Dungeons and Dragons.  In fact, the list of things that are different from pen and paper D&D would be far shorter than the huge list of things that are exactly spot on.It just feels right.  If you want to jump and attack with your sworrd, you push a button to jump, and another to attack.  If you want to turn while doing that, then you're gonna need to push a button to turn, as well.  The combat is what they'd call in a space game "twitchy."  The only clickies on your toolbar are gonna be spells and special abilities - and there are plenty of those and that's fun.  I've read that DDO features "the most immersive combat online," and that's really how it feels.  You feel like YOU are there, fighting some ♥♥♥♥ing kobolds or whatever.  I remember back when I first started playing and I fell down in the kobold prison in the Waterworks with my 2nd level wizard.  I literally had a freakin' panic attack because it truly felt like the end of the world - a very terrible situation.  Somehow I fought my way out of there, and it's like I actually survived something.  I actually got sick from anxiety - which was great. My wife and I spent 11 hours in the Proof in the Poison quest one night.  Another, both our characters were in their skivvies buidling a freakin' human chain in the pitch dark to try and cross a pit of spears - in Rainbow in the Dark . . .Which is to say, some of these quests we actually recall as if they were REAL trials overcome.  They're in our real book of memories, so to speak.  I can't think of another game that's had the impact on me.In terms of expansiveness, not only is the world of DDO huge, it's so big now you don't even have to explore it all to advance all the way to the upper ranks.  And not only that, but movement in the world never feels "fake."  If you get to the end of the Halls of Shan-to-Kor or you reach the Burning City in the Sands of Menechtarun, you feel like you have done some hiking, by god - and you're likely terrified some Drow rangers may still be following you.I don't know . . .  It's not perfect.  There's some newer ♥♥♥♥ I find cheesy, but even as I criticize DDO I still think it's the best.  The complaints I see about it . . . well, those aren't things I'd complain much about.  Being censored for hate speech?  Sheez, yeah.  Good riddance, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.    P2W?  Yeah, I guess I can see that - but the F2P stuff is extensive and by the time I ever decided to pay a penny I was well and truly immersed in the game and I felt the enjoyment I had was well worth every penny.  Turbine are incompetent?  Yeah, okay, but then again I've had to deal with Turbine maybe three times in, like, seven years.  The game runs pretty damn well.Overall, it's hard to describe what is different about this game.  If you've tried all kinds of D&D or fantasy MMO's, and you've come to the end of the line with them all, then don't give up on the genre without trying DDO.  The game is full of a lot of players who have come back to it again and again, as I have.  Its following is loyal, and they're the same folks who are purists regarding Dungeons and Dragons proper.  Fans of 3.5 I should say.Hell, I'm just praying for DDO2 - and hoping the make it exactly the same as this one, except with cloaks and horses.  No ♥♥♥♥.

content:
14, 2016
												(Only recently installed through Steam, I have at least a few thousand hours logging in directly through the client and several characters at level cap).The core game is very good, but the actual experience is plagued with bugs, performance issues and questionable management. Play for free for a while, then decide if you want to commit.- Gameplay: Positional, third person action RPG based on D&D rules. All the main classes and races are here, and they play as you would expect from the pen and paper (but obviously with different skills and powers due to the different natures of the games). Gameplay is fast, rewards correct positioning and physically dodging attacks and spells is not only viable, but often required. It's more than just amassing big number, even though that's obviously the main goal and the measure of progression.- Customization: The main strenght of the game. You can mix and match up to three classes on each character, and (almost) each class has 3 skill trees to pick from. No other restricions apply. You can melee with a mage, throw shurikens with a paladin or wield greathammers with a gnome warlock. Tons of loot, (frankly too many) crafting systems and special, named items from various quests. Many cosmetic choices for armor and helmets, not so much for the rest of the equipment.- Longevity: Over 400 quests (see Business Model below) and a couple dozen raids, which means you can play hundreds of hours to fully explore all content. Quality of course will vary: some revamped classic modules are really good (Haunted Halls of Eveningstar), while many older quests are a bit bland, grey and uninteresting. The main trick however is reincarnation: get to level cap and start again from scratch, with small incremental benefits and the ability to completely reshape the character (including race, class, skills, appearance). The game is based around the concept of performing several reincarnation, growing progressively in power as those boni stacks and you ammass a larger stash of equipment.- Business model: The premium currency can be earned ingame, so in theory you could experience the entirety of the game for free. That's one of the fairest business models I've encountered, as far as content goes. Turbine, however, is pretty obviously warping a few mechanics around the shop, sadly: a few crafting systems (including some raid rewards) can be bypassed with cash, and the difference is noticeable. I'm ok with convenience and cosmetics (bank space, character slots, cosmetic items, xp boosts), not so much with buying raw power, raw xp and in general progressing without running the content.- The bad: The game is 10 years old and it shows. It's not graphically impressive, animations are generally bad and you can count polygons on most environments. It's also obviously built on spaghetti code, and every update something completely unrelated breaks and is even fixed way too late, fixed partially or left there. I've experienced crippling lag. I've died for no reason while walking. I've had the game eat my ingredients without rewarding me. I've heard of people losing items while banking them. You need to learn all the quirks of the game and play around them (as in "kill this now or we'll lag out and fail", or "don't use the bank in this area").My suggestion is to roll a couple of characters, experience the free content as long as one can, buy a couple of adventure packs with the ingame currency earned and by that time you will realize if you want to keep playing. It's a shame a good game is plagued by technical issues and questionable design choices, but what is unacceptable for someone who's been playing for 6 years may be unnoticable to a new player. There is no risk in trying it out.

Some of the BEST times of my life are in this game.. And i want to thank Turbine for that.. 100/10 rating for me

content:
y 11, 2014
												This is a fairly fun game and I'd suggest giving it a decent try. It does attempt to cover various groups. Can solo most quests. But if can run with one or more friends, that would be more fun. Or make friends within a guild. Even running with random people (PUG) is usually good if choose carefully.Public areas permit a large number of people (note, not PVP). However the number of people that can enter a specific quest or adventure area is 6 and with raids 12 (special events may have more). That number does include hirelings (and also the not-great owlbear from Shadowfell collectors edition) but excludes summons, companions, pets.There are currently about 100 free quests and about 250 quests that are paid (by quest pack or by expansion). There are quite a bit more free quests below level 10 than above level 10. There are also almost 20 raids and around 30 adventure areas and maybe 10 challenges. And some PVP areas that are ignored by almost everyone.Do need to get packs and expansions? I would say that if enjoy the game then consider doing so. Yes can earn turbine points to buy the packs, but for many that isn't a great use of their time. Note purchase of a pack is for all characters for all servers forever. Or go VIP and have access to all packs. However VIP memberships do NOT include expansions.One note on VIP is that it can open up hard and elite difficulty. I find hard difficulty is a great choice for many newer players (and still a very good choice for more experienced non-expert players at higher levels). Note other account types can also open a quest on other difficulties either by completing on a lower difficulty or by a cheap store item (or in the same party with someone that can access the higher difficulties).Everyone have their own favorite packs. Gianthold pack is argueably the most recommended pack as it has lots of quests at both heroic (13-14) and elite (23-25) levels. Can search for recommend packs. But keep in mind of your play style, the usefulness of the pack and how much you might enjoy the pack. For example, I like bright cheerful explorer areas so picked up the Three barrel cove pack - a pack that is often not recommended.The catacombs starter pack isn't too bad. The quests are somewhat interesting (opinions vary of course). As this is a purchase, will automatically bring account to premium status. Note the permenant gold seal hireling is only one per account per server so if don't have shared bank (included with VIP and a recommended option for other account types), so make sure you login to the correct character after you enable that pack. That hireling is useful for those soloing to give you an extra hand to deal with some quests mechanics, and especially with a character that uses spell points as the hireling can restore some spell points back to you. Note must be level 3 minimum to summon that hireling. For a VIP, less benefit. Note can always buy non-permenant gold seal hirelings from the ddo store.Expansions? Menace of underdark is recommended once reach level 16+. If it includes the Attack on Stormreach pack then would be useful earlier (level 13 pack). By level 20, it is highly suggested. (note max level is currently 28, will reach 30 by end of 2014 and unlikely to ever increase beyond that).Shadowfell expansion - I got it, not thrilled. But as the number of quests at epic levels 26 to 28 is quite low (but growing) so for now could be useful.Combat is very dynamic, or can be. Can always just stand in front of some monster and whack away. If can kill very quickly or have enough healing or high defense and especially at lower difficulties (casual/normal) and on stupider creatures that can work. But combat often is not like that as can move around, use terrain, dodge attacks and use various tactics. Notice what an opponent is doing / about to do and react to that. e.g. hard to shoot someone with arrows or with a ray spell if the target keeps moving or runs behind a pillar.Grouping - this game permits characters to reincarnate back to level 1 multiple times. These characters are called TRs. Other people may like to run many different types of charcters (alts). So this means that in a random group you might have one or more that is familiar with the quests and what lies within (note if repeat a quest will notice that does do not vary too much, although difficulty selected will have a significant impact). And they are often equiped somewhat better to way better than a newer character. Although noticeable at low levels, it is very noticable around level 12 for greensteel equiped TRs. These people often just want to complete the quest efficently/quickly (usually on elite) and as they already know the quest, they don't need to investigate or explore. This can give a false impression that a quest is easy and dramatically decrease how long it takes to do the quest (e.g. a few minutes instead of 30+ minutes for a group that isn't familar with the quest). Groups are usually labelled as Elite BB, Zerg or BYOH or similar. Suggest if don't want that type of group to post one yourself saying no zerg or not a speed run or similar.Graphics, primarly on the older quests can be dated. But it does work fairly well with low end graphic cards. There is also higher quality graphics mostly in forgotten realms that can take full advantage of a high end graphics card. Some people say they prefer the graphics style in DDO over many other mmos, so whatever. Some of the images on the DDO steam page looks like images from a few years ago and is currently is significantly better.Other notes: When starting the game, you are immediately in a quest. The whole island has several quests. However keep in mind these are fairly simple quests to show some of the facets of the game. And no, a rogue/artificer is not necessary to do any of the quests (there are a few optional chests and some traps that can be timed). Hiring the level 1 cleric hireling is recommened (costs a few coins). And if your character can cast spells, strongly suggest to take the Archivist's Necklace for the Misery's peak reward. Enjoy the journey, don't race to get to the end, many of the most popular quests are at many different levels. And especially true as the end game is being revamped with the level cap increase to 28 a few months ago and then finally to 30 at the end of this year.Races. The base races are good.For premium races, Warforge is very popular for wizard and sorcerer (and artificer) due to strong self heal capabilities.Purchase of drow is not suggested as it is easy to earn access to the drow in game (only 400 favor to unlock drow for the server).Half orc and half elf, are not too popular as the free human race is usually a better choice. Note half-elf is the ugliest race. Gnomes are not yet available.Iconics start a character at level 15. Although not too bad for TRs and alts, for most new players I would not suggest starting with an iconic. Some iconics may be included in some versions of the shadowfell expansion.Classes: The base classes are also good. (although paladin and especially bard are often viewed as weaker choices)For premium classes, Artificer is a considered as a fairly strong choice. It can be gained with favor (not easily...). However for me the repeating crossbow sound was so annoying that switched to different combat style...Monk is considered as a strong choice for, especially if like active combat style with lots of buttons and manoeuvring around. Also popular for multiclassing with 2 (or more) levels of monk such as with fighter, cleric, artificer, wizard, etc.Favored Soul use to be quite popular, now not so much... maybe when 3rd prestige is available it will be popular again.Druid is okayish. Some can get it to work quite well, for me... meh. Might be included if get some versions of the Menance of the underdark expansion.Done.

												DD is literally the best game i have played. From the action combat to the traps in dungeons its awesome. Another plus is that almost any pc can run it decently. There are plenty of toutorials to help you through the game so i would highly suggest at least trying it. If its not for you then whatever you just had a bit of fun and passed some time!

content:
16, 2015
												Okay, so I'll be the first to admit that this is not the MMO for everyone. It is rather dated, has a few issues once in a while, and lacks some of the quality of life features of some newer MMO's. However, it is a character builder's dream, with the ability to endlessly tinker with various builds and classes and the freedom to build your character however you want, with stats, skills, and feats freely allocated allowing for clever and unique builds for those who want to try something new and impressive optimization for power gamers. The community is by and large decent, and while there are probably a few bad apples, I haven't had any terrible experiences. The game is both solo and party friendly, and the more recalcitrant solo players can bring along hirelings, AI companions, to help out if the going gets tough. Dungeons can be run on four difficulties, a pansy mode for cowardly weaklings, a normal mode for weaklings, a hard mode for regular players, and expert for power builds! (Okay, I generalized there.) There is a lot of content for free, and subscribing unlocks access to most of the content for a monthly fee. Otherwise, you can buy or earn turbine points to get content packs to expand your experience. The cash shop is prevalent and offers advantages, but free to play is sufficient to get a good start in the game and there's not really a crippling disadvantage to free players that would force them to pay.

content:
25
												Great game over all, tons of character options. If you like the neverwinter nights games or baulder's gate, this is like the psuedo mmo version of them.It can be a little confusing for begginers to figure out mid game, but the community is helpful.It gets harder to solo later in game, which is unfourtnate and all too common in mmo types of games. (Probably a big reason so many games failed to be the WoW killer, WoW understood the value of solo support). You can have your AI hirling pick up your soul stone when you die so you won't go out of range of it when you walk around as a spirit, then you can make your way back to a rez shrine, but if your hirling dies too, then you have to respawn and re-enter the dungeon. You get a exp penalty for that. It's a good system, abiet counter intuitive, and if you want to play solo avoid doign dungeons on anythign more than normal if you are new.The pay to play for access to certain areas, I find kind of dumb. The game should never split up parties because one doesn't have the certain dlc they need. I wish they would find a better way to monetize, do what warframe does or something. Anyway, it's definitely worth trying out. 8/10

content:
25
												I recently got into this game because my wife and her brother used to play the crap out of it when it first released. Now we have a full party of family members all playing together. If you enjoy D&D 3.5, you'll be glad to know that every rule in the game came straight from the tabletop books, to including multi-classing. It sticks true to its roots of the original format, but also makes a pretty good MMO. The community is also very friendly from what I've seen (Khyber server) which I assume is because it's age (and possibly it's limitations on free players, more on that later) has driven off the bulk of players, leaving only the ones who really enjoy it.As a note, this game released 11 years ago, and while I personally appreciate that it doesn't need a dream machine to run smoothly, people who are accustomed to 4k HD might find it off-putting. Also, if you have a friend (or a few) who you're going to play with, I highly recommend using a third-party chat system such as Discord, as I don't think that the in-game mic chat has been updated since 2006.The only fundamental problem with the game is that as a free-to-play, free players have a bit more limitation than what I've seen in other games. This could actually be the reason why the community is so nice, but I digress. There are a few races and a few classes and even several missions that are only available to those who purchase VIP, but if you don't mind spending a little money I highly recommend giving it a whirl.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2014
												I don't understand how (since the unfortunate and untimely demise of SWG), anyone can play any other MMORPG.  I mean, in all fairness, other titles might have the advantage of being a venerable title (WOW), or have a massive fan following (either FF XI/XIV), but when it all comes down to style, playability, and taking full advantage of the MMO perks, by incorporating them into the games construction, DDO, has done exactly what it set out to do...Emulate the adventures of the pen & paper game that has reached critical acclaim from loyal fans the world over.All the versatility of the tabletop format is right here at your fingertips.  You want to customize your stats and feats to build the most critical to form shield & sword knight, emphasizing value of honor and virtue, or become a shadow walker with deft fingers and mythic ability?  You can.  In fact, you can be both at the same time!Multiclass?  Yes, please!  I found myself easily bored by other MMO's and their linearal ability trees; maxing out my characters to get a taste of their potential, only to wish that there was more I was capable of doing.WOW?  Pffft... not if the game paid me!  DDO is the closest experience to the tabletop format as you can possibly get, without actually drawing up a world yourself.And trust me, if you enjoy this game for even a minute, do yourself a favour, go pick up some dice.  When you experience all that D&D can be, you'll never turn your back.  It's the ultimate high.

content:
ry 2, 2014
												The best MMORPG game I've played (and I've played a lot of different ones).It's got it's fair share of bugs, and it can be laggy in some situations. It's not very well opimised so people with slow hard drives, and not very powerful computers might have issues.But despite this, it's still kept my interest for many years.It's got great character customisation (although sadly not as much cosmetic customisation as I would like), and lots of interesting quests.The only down side is that while it is technecally a free to play game, and you can infact play it for free. Getting past level 14 or so becomes very hard due to there being few free to play quests after that point. You can unlock more quests by earning pay for money in game, but it's very time consuming to do so, and becomes easier the more content you have unlocked (so it's harder to do to start with).It lets you really try the game out though, and I would recomend anyone who likes the game to spend at least a bit of money in order to change their account from free to play to a premium account (unlocks permanently after you spend any amount of money on the game). Doing so lifts a lot of restrictions on your account.Other than that, the only thing that I can think to say is that the comunity created wiki for the game is your friend in this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2014
												I've played this game for years now (way, way before it was on steam which I honestly just moved to) and it has been a great game. It's a really great game honestly and I love it. The creators are still supporting in and releasing updates and it's pretty awesome. However it's player base has started to dwindle and that is hurting it a lot. It was never what you could call high profile but it did have a crap ton of players on it. But now it can be hard to find others. It's possible to get around this if you know what to look for though. First of all, play during the day, esp. on weekends and there will be a good number of people around. Second of all, be careful what server you pick as characters can't move between them. To get around this I suggest using Argonnessen (you might have to scroll to find it). It has a really active player community still and there are a lot of guilds looking for players. Third, JOIN A GUILD PLEASE, just do it, if you are having a hard time finding people that's probably because you aren't in one. It helps, a lot, it really does. As far as finding one goes, hang around the harbor or korthos island (after you kill the dragon, you can't join one before that) and someone will probably try and recruit you to their guild. I know a guild (not mine, I founded my own a while ago and try and keep it kind of small) called Tycoons of Tommorow has been really active lately as well as really into recruiting, so they would be a good choice. Fourth, if a guild isn't helping or your fellow members aren't logged in, use the social pannel. It's there for a reason. It's made to show you all parties looking for members to do a quest. If you want to do a quest that isn't on that list, create your own looking for members party (the tool to do so is also in the social pannel). On the issue of FTP, that lasts for about 7 to 8 levels (that's a lot more than you think, you have to rank up 5 times per level and ranking up is a lot like what leveling is in another game) so you can still get some play time in before you run in to that really badly. HOWEVER, remember this is a bussiness, the company has to make money otherwise they can't have a game so eventually they need you to buy something. Don't get upset about this if you don't want to pay, go play flash games or something online it doesn't really matter. If you are willing to get over that, be willing to pay a little, you can get a subscription or buy individual content. I suggest buying the individual content which you do through the in game store, it's not too expensive and it never expires so it's a lot like buying DLC content for another game. Next DON'T expect this to be the pen and pencil game. It's different, HOWEVER, it really did inherit the heart and soul of D&D. Character building is almost strait out of D&D 3.5 edition and is very (almost deceptively) complex. It's easy to mess up so read a couple tutorials or pick a default build. Whatever you do, don't play the wizard, pick sorcerer, they do everything better and both are free. Wizards just really suck on non-reencarated builds. For beginners I suggest picking the Barbarian or Paladin classes. Both are really good and easy to play (Paladins just got an update and are stupidly powerful right now, I would go with a Human or Dwarf Paladin). Player abilities take a little ispiration from 4.0 (good things not all the terribleness) so that you don't have to make a lot of basic attacks and it's really intuitive. Quests are also really nice as long as you aren't too concerned with your exp. per minute (which honestly just takes the fun out of the game). Take your time and read and listen to the stories, they are pretty great. And lastly just have fun with it. It's free at first so it doesn't hurt at all to try. So come on and play, If you are on Agronnessen and you see a character with the surname Requiem, say hi, I'll see if I can't help you get started.

content:
2, 2015
												Really glaring flaws that are really putting me off.Melee combat is very hit or miss, I enjoyed it on a monk but a dual rapier rogue ended up being a nightmare at some points,(maybe it was the attack speed?) if the enemy chooses to move at all you will have just about no chance of hitting them and this will happen frequently against casters. Maybe this was just from the last dungeon I was in but I was not able to hit the orcs at all once they moved, and they moved VERY frequently when hit, and it took a moment after they stopped before I would be able to continue dealing damage.  I was doing very well in a dungeon three levels higher than I was supposed to be in but these things seriously hampered my progress to a point where I had to completely stop and leave, I will never step foot in that area again because it was a very nasueating experience having orc casters with blur and negative level abilities constantly shift to avoid damage made them literally unhittable, it was an actual brick wall.NPC spellcasters that are not your hirelings have an infinite amount of spellpoints, so anything you fight will never run out of an infinite font of fuel to burn your ♥♥♥ to the floor. If you try to wait any negative levels (feels like three minutes+ per negative level..) you incur they will continue to spread buffs, and the moment you get in range you get slapped with even more.The dungeons are really neat when its not go left or right into rooms that have nothing but filler mobs with a few crates that *might* contain something worth selling and for the conquest and ransack xp boosts. Although I feel like for this reason there are some quests that arent really even viable to do because they are just way too long and you could have done much more in that time. I don't even think this review is done but these were just some thoughts so far.
