content:
y 5
												Caution: Old school Pen and Paper Geek, review will be slantedI played DDO on and off for over 2 years and even had a premium content pack or two, but I just gave up. The initial Character mechanic LOOKS like the DnD 3.X, but the deeper layers of the game are built in a fashion to any other MMO. Just because I know what my character can handle on paper doesn't mean my Online character stands a chance. Looking into the forums and fan pages, I leaned that just like WoW/Everquest/et al, the game was built using an engine that encourages decimal point maxing that's even more Munchkin than pen and paper games. If you want to play solo, don't bother. The "perfect builds" have been long since logged and the macro routines are freely traded, thus turning the game into less of a skill/luck game and into a "press this key to execute this routine". The player population is slim and too many tropes from other games have crept into DDO over the years like meta currency, Alliance based items and abilities and a subtle but painful need to chain play content packs for gear in order to stand a chance at higher levels (as a soloist, I suck at group play).It just isn't DnD anymore. It has the window dressing at the front end, but it's just a grinder. I disbanded my Alliance, deleted my toons and gave up.

At least the character creation is very extensive. I've always liked that.

content:
25, 2016
The Best [Free to Play/Pay to Play] Game in existance currently!Alright so to start off this review lets talk about what the game of [DDO] actually is.[DDO] Is a F2P hack n' slash style MMORPG with a dungeon crawling theme to it. The game has quite a bit of Pay to progress content that players can either choose to pay in order to get it, or use the "favor system" in order to get content for free just by playing. The game also offers many elements that help the replayability immensley, which I will talk about laterPROS & CONSPROS    1. You can attain all of the content for FREE.    2. You can solo and or group in the game if you want to.    3. The game has immense customization, meaning that you have the ability to build your character completely different than other players every time If you want to    4. The game has a system in which you can True Reincarnate once you reach level cap. This means that you will go from level cap back to level 1, with benefits from your previous (life).CONS    1. STUDY STUDY STUDY - - Unless you really enjoy studying to better understand a game in order to become the best, then this part is a CON for you. Studying can be VERY beneficial in this game, however it can be the down fall of this game for many players as well.    2. PvP - - There is PvP within this game, however it isn't really good. If you are looking for a PvP based game, then I advise you to go to another MMO.    3. Groups - - This game certainly isn't for everyone, it takes a bit of work to get into, so finding groups to play with can be challenging. You have to put yourself way more out there, in order to find other players to talk to/group with.     4. GRAPHICS - - Now I personally dont mind games with bad graphics, however some players might. This games graphics can be hard on the eyes when players are used to games such as... (Skyrim, Blade & Soul, Black Desert, etc)    5. GRIND - - This game is a major grind, since the entire goal behind this game is to utilize the (True Reincarnation system). If you dont wish to utilize that system, then you are better off playing something else.Looking at the Pros/Cons you might be wondering, "Why...? Why would this guy recommend this game to me?" Well I will tell you. This game may be finicky, it might require a bit more time invested into it in order to enjoy it, however this game has 2 essential elements that many other games lack.    1. Character Difference    2. Reason to continue playing that characterA lot of the MMOs out there these days lack in both of those areas... With [DDO], You will be able to differentiate your character by selecting things such as, (Race, Class, Alignment, Feats, Skills, Enhancements, Weapons, Armor, Stats, Selecting up to 3 different classes, etc.)You will also be able to continue to improve upon that character by following through with the (True Reincarnation system). This will make it so a level capped character can go back to the beginning with benefits acquired from your past life.These 2 elements is what makes [DDO] superior to games like [World of warcraft] For example. What is it that players from [World of warcraft] do once they reach the end game area? They get the best in slot gear, then what do you do? They might do some PvP. Then what do you do? They get gold capped. Then what do you do? The game is pretty much dead for you after that right? At least... unless a new update/expac comes to pass perhaps. Yes, [DDO] does get more updates to the gear, and if you dont like to grind, then this game definitely is NOT for you.Now, im not the best at writing reviews however, I certainly recommend to anyone that is seeking a new MMO, to try out [DDO]. The game is definitely worth a look, and it wont cost anything to just download it and hop in for a bit guaranteed :).

content:
2014
												DDO is probably the most underratred MMO out there. I wish more games in the genre would use modular content like this one does. It allows you to solo and make groups on the fly while still enjoying the content, and you never feel like you have to twiddle your thumbs waiting for a "healer" or "tank" to show up. It's an altogether better system than the traditional MMO in many ways. The free account is limited in that you can only create two characters and they will be removed if you don't log on for a while - which makes me sad, because I really play this as kind of a pick-up-and-go game and I don't like to pay subscription fees for MMOs. That said, the game itself is definitely worth your time if you're looking for a free to play MMORPG that actually has some depth to it. It can be difficult to find other players to group with because the player base is small. It's still a very enjoyable game, and if you're even vaguely familiar with D&D 3.5 rules you'll get into it pretty easily. I only know the very basic gameplay and I was able to jump into this without too many issues. The leveling system is more complex and robust than a typical mmo, but the game has features that allow you to select a goal. The game then builds toward that goal for you. It's a fun game to play causally. I would play more often if I had a regular group to play with.

If you like coop rpg's and adventure games, this one is for you. Join the Thelanis server and we shall slay!

content:
y 1, 2015
												DDO is a great game filled with meticulous character planning, questing, leveling and even more character planning. Despite how it sounds, it's actually very pleasing. Overall gameplay experiences are positive and it's not bad on the eye either. DDO brings outstanding events (mabar, crystal cove, etc.), and I found these to be extremely rewarding. However, I'm kind of sad to see DDO becoming less and less D&D in an attempt to please a more mainstream crowd. I greatly enjoyed playing it over the past years, but I find myself playing less for exactly that reason. Every update comes with it's own set of new bugs and support is sloppy. Every update seems to make the game more profit oriented, the gaming experience coming in second place. And I'll admit, I have spent my fair share of money, with no regrets. PROs:- Hours of fun. Find yourself a capable, well balanced party and you'll be having a good time.- A variety of different locations, each with their own inhabitants, all equally eager to knock you down a peg.- A very supportive communityCONs- After hours of gameplay, going from TR to TR becomes quite a grind.- "Incompetent" (By lack of a better word) parties will prolong a quest greatly. This is not always a problem, but can be quite aggrevating when it takes 3 hours to complete a seemingly simple raid.- Bugs and poor fixes.- Quest mechanics have been changed, making it next to impossible to do a quest solo.TL;DRDDO is still good, it just used to be better.

content:
er 8, 2014
												Well, the most lovely and complex MMO for me since 2006 (based on AD&D + special rules). I really not want to admit how much hours i played since 2006 with this game...(since 2006 it's 5-6hr average daily base mostly on evenings, and i'm not a 24/7-er and never will be; nowadays have some months retirement from DDO... there are some guys who plays a lot lot lot more. Lowlifers? Millionaires? Workslackers? Gnomes in the basement as daddy's/mommy's favourite thing? Guess i will never know that...)I can recommend this if you like to build unique characters and try so much things what can offer this game, and if you like AD&D. It's still the best choice what can offer the market around for hardcore rpg mmo...+ instanced quest system+ deep character, class and reincarnation possiblities+ good story content with lot of hidden and less hidden clues+ secret places, TRAPS!+ "free to play" made a great blast for the community, but you really need to 'work' hard if you not want to pay for this game, if you want to unlock the whole content (to be "raid or fast reincarnation compatible" mostly)+ team game, but if you have a good idea/build/amount of time/skill/persistence, almost every time can figurable how can be possible to solo any quest (even raids)+ guilds and shipping (housing)- graphics a bit outdated, but the main thing is the athmosphere, so can live with that- random characterization is a bit outdated- encourage to break the whole furniturement in the dungeons (you get extra xp for that), it's still SILLY!- unsolved bugs since 2006 (the most famous one: the ladder 'bug', which is extremely annoying), and every new expansion seems to be a problem to not cause unwanted bugs in the implemented older contents, so usually worth to wait a bit after they release a new one (well it can be true nowadays for so many overhype-marketed games also)- ocassional LAG and sudden disconnections, sometimes non-planned maintenence- favor of the month builds, which suggest serious content balance failures, but the developers always follow how to fix that... and of course encourage people to roll a new 'trendy' build for the success...- ingame purchase: if your wallet is big, you can progress much faster -> reincarnation hearts, +50% experience pots, tomes etc.

content:
er 10, 2014
												1. Do not think of this game as free to play. You "Could" get every piece of content in the game for free, but it is highly time inefficient and soul-suckingly boring for the average person. requiring roughly 20 hours to get 1000 Turbine points (the Shop currency) also known as 10$. 2. Since I have asked you to suspend your current beliefs I will supply you with some new ones. This game should be thought of as a 25$ game when on one of their deep discount sales on steam for christmas (mabye), black friday, or any other sale where you can pick up the two expansions, or a 15$ a month Subscription with free premium currency as mini rewards as you play. Remember that you can buy most adventure packs for $3 to $10 with a few exceptions. You also do not have to buy all of the packs. some can be ignored because they are not your cup of tea.3. Sales. Learn them. This game becomes a much better sell once you realize they have weekly sales every week on thursday and friday with discounts on things you actually care about like adventure packs or occasionaly one of the premium classes.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 19, 2014
												After 400 + hours of this dealing with bugs and everything, i can safely say that this is like a love hate relationship. You wan't this game to be so good but the bugs constantly slap your immersion right in the face.Would i wan't the hours i played back, no. Do i wan't the game to improve yes.If you have ever played pen & paper like i did, this is a easy to digest version somewhat of the old d & d games. But it plays like an mmo of course. Theres starting to be a large variety of classes now to melt into eachother with reckless abandon. Some builds are extremely good and some are very gimped.It takes the action based approach to a really cool place, which i really like. But that said some of its features are lacking in the sense that it's crafting system never fully matured. The large raids require a large amount of guidance, and can fail badly and quickly because of large amounts of dammage  huge demands to mana. They removed monks ability to ressurect people which was a huge boon and needed in my opinion.Small pets that do nothing, no mounts and no housing. Those are things id like to see in the future. And the really cool story based dungeons could lift the game somewhat, with not to much downtime mind you, it sucks to wait for minutes just looking at narration.Well if you are new to the game and are looking for a guild, im on sarlona with my own guild Nobles of Evenstar.

content:
ber 1, 2015
												I came across this when I couldn't find a decent gaming group near me to play Pen & Paper DnD.I haven't played it on Steam for a long while (Because technical reasons), but I'm pretty sure my hours played are at least double, if not triple the amount above.It's not a carbon copy of PnP considering it's made for MMO purposes (I mean, come on, you don't REALLY want to wait six seconds for every single action, do you?) but it's a pretty good representation of it.A dedicated player can play this game and eventually* access all its content without needing to pay a single penny.One thing that makes this game stand out from many others out there is its replayability.Your character isn't capped at its full potential when you reach max level, no.You can "Reincarnate" characters to make them stronger on recreation, giving them extra perks and bonuses, allowing you to build a better character from level 1 without deleting and re-creating it.With time, you can go through all the Classes with a single character, no need to create different characters for different classes, though you can still do that, if you so choose.It's also a rather friendly community overall, so don't hesitate to always ask for help in-game!*After excessive grinding across multiple servers for currency you can use in the in-game Store.

content:
ry 16, 2014
												So here it is, another hidden Gem in the list of free to play games.  this game has been out for awhile, I was around 18 years old when I heard about it, I gave it try back then, now 5 years later (2014). Ive came back, I felt like i didnt give it much of a chance and holly crap what an amazing experience Ive been having, I plugged my Afterglow 360 controller in, touched up to controlls to how I prefer and jumped into a  flawless well polished game, that new what it wanted toe be, a serious RPG for D&D fanseverything including the gameplay, naratives, character customization which keeps things challenging to the way that you crawl over the land scape and grab onto ledges  this is what keep D&D titles alive. simple concepts like puzzles and having to search areas, this is the ultimate MMO, I recently played Elderscrolls Online, and honestly I love the ideas and how much loot you can pick up, and how you can see your hands when in first person, how every AI talks to you with sound, but honestly it takes you outta the reality of being immersive, DDO has the kinda Graphics that grow on you, it looks kinda clunky at first but when you toss DX11 on you start to really love how it all blends together, this is a game that is looked past by many, for those who really feen for a solid well polished RPG look no further this is the ultimate pakage, join the legacy  11/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 1, 2015
												DDO is a great game filled with meticulous character planning, questing, leveling and even more character planning. Despite how it sounds, it's actually very pleasing. Overall gameplay experiences are positive and it's not bad on the eye either. DDO brings outstanding events (mabar, crystal cove, etc.), and I found these to be extremely rewarding. However, I'm kind of sad to see DDO becoming less and less D&D in an attempt to please a more mainstream crowd. I greatly enjoyed playing it over the past years, but I find myself playing less for exactly that reason. Every update comes with it's own set of new bugs and support is sloppy. Every update seems to make the game more profit oriented, the gaming experience coming in second place. And I'll admit, I have spent my fair share of money, with no regrets. PROs:- Hours of fun. Find yourself a capable, well balanced party and you'll be having a good time.- A variety of different locations, each with their own inhabitants, all equally eager to knock you down a peg.- A very supportive communityCONs- After hours of gameplay, going from TR to TR becomes quite a grind.- "Incompetent" (By lack of a better word) parties will prolong a quest greatly. This is not always a problem, but can be quite aggrevating when it takes 3 hours to complete a seemingly simple raid.- Bugs and poor fixes.- Quest mechanics have been changed, making it next to impossible to do a quest solo.TL;DRDDO is still good, it just used to be better.

content:
r 10, 2016
												I am write this review while waiting for Turbine to fix my account, which isn't connecting due to a "Lack of subscription" when the game is F2P.Supprisingly It isn't negative one. DDO was my first involved experiance with FTP+Micro transactions, and I have to say when I'd last played they where doing it right. There was no functional item in the Real Payment stores that didn't have an equivilant you could work for, and overall it is one of the best executions of the entire format. In a game with +4 weapons, and the store caped at +3. Utility items that open locks 50x , so you don't lose out of treasure just because your playing a Paladin who doesn't pick locks. You can clear out an area, and over time loot and sell items to get that NPC contract so you have a dedicated healer. Or you can fork over five bucks and get one from the store. Classes feel different, and the feat system works similar to the classic Pen and Paper game. And they have implemented skills in a way that very few skills don't at least have some appeal. Swim might seem useless, until you are trying to solve a puzzel on a water level, and you just ran out of water breathing potions. The hidden cap of 40 could of been adressed, perhaps giving some minor bonus elsewhere depending on the skill.The only complaint I ever really had was how slow leveling up felt, each level subdivided into 5 mini-levels. However the very thing that is drawing me back is that recent updates have given me hope that they may now feel more substantial with a talent tree like interface. Lastly, I will say that if you do decide to play. Steam does not have anything to do with the account and login. That is Turbine. And they have the Worst Website of ANY MMO i've seen. Even those random Korean games that where popular some time back are better. It honestly feels like they hired somone to take care of it, then fired them a week before launch, and never hired anyone to fix it. Supposidly if you become a "Premium Member" (You've payed ~$10 or more) you get actual customer support to help deal with your issues, but as i've said, i'm waiting on a ticket.Overall I'd give it a try. That at the very least cost nothing. And the game really can be played without ever paying a cent, although expect to do a lot of grinding to get everything.

er 23, 2016
												DDO is a great game with detailed character creation and awesome combat mechanics. You can do a lot for free, which is spelled out well in the ddowiki article[ddowiki.com].If you are new to the game, be sure try all the servers until you find one with a lot of activity during your play time. At least one server has a player character acting as a greeter in the starter area. If you like to hammer things out for yourself, you can do that. If you like socialization, grouping, and getting help in game, you can do that, too. There a lot of helpful players, and when you find and join an active guild, you will have constant comrades. :)*Don't mind my Steam playing time. I have been playing DDO long before I joined Steam. ;)Edit:This is a great game, and it has been one for years. If you are used to playing other MMO's, you would do well to forget them when you play DDO. Approach the game with a fresh perspective, and bring along some friends. You will not be sorry. :)

content:
29, 2014
												I used to think this game was the epitome of great in spite of both dated graphics and logistics....because 3.5 is the only DnD version worth playing (Baldur's Gate, NWN, Icewind, etc.), but the game is dying.  Sad, but true.  The game needs a reboot with a new engine, and I truly believe such a reboot would attract a large player base, but it's doubtful that such a thing will ever happen.  There has been a serious dumbing down in the difficulty of content such that most PUGs are with individuals who feel entitled to a win without working for it.  Strategy?  Unknown.  Entitlement?  Yes, now.  While that description by no means encompasses every player it fairly describes such a prevelant sentiment that the enjoyment of the game is in a steady decline and has been so for a quite some time.  Also, the last year or so has seen Pay-To-Win options introduced on their store, further degrading the player base and removing motivators for continued play while lining the pockets of Turbine.  Gear is handed out like candy, through duping or otherwise.  With no real motivators to be better, skill declines.  Unless you're the kind of player who likes easy walks in the park and readily accessible gear for all, then this is not the game for you.What once was good now needs a burial plot at the nearest cemetary.R.I.P. DDO

content:
28, 2014
												This game is amazing. It's graphics and combat give it a classic feel, and even though it looks old, it is updated regularly and has a large amount of players. The quests and dungeons are interesting and immersive. There are large "Wilderness" areas filled with monsters and places to explore, and they even have a few rare named monsters! The dungeons are exceedingly fun, with many different monsters and 4 different difficulty settings that effect XP earned. Choose Casual and go through it lone wolf, or go Elite and bring a few friends along to conquer all those who oppose you! Grouping in this game is fun, as you learn to depend on one-another when in danger. The crafting system is a little boring, but it is absolutely rewarding. Armor and Weapon designs are cool and flashy, with multiple different armor sets for diversity. Combat is fun, with weapons having hitboxes and a certain reach based on their weapon type. There are somewhere around 15 classes, all of which are interesting and fun to play. The game features a multiclass system, so you can make your character exactly what you want it to be. Whether you're a mage with a huge greataxe, a stealthy tank, or a magical rogue, whatever you want to be is entirely up to you.9/10, You must try this game.

, 2014
												As one of the original founders (my guild's name, Gtb, is still on the monument), I returned after some years to the game in the hopes of enjoying it once more. A poor decision on my part, I'm afraid.The game says "free to play," but, in fact, the game is a microtransaction farm. It's sparsely populated, and the only way for your wallet to survive is to join a guild - in this game, if you're playing solo, understand that death has a dollar sign attached to it. And, you're going to die a lot. The game's mechanics have encouraged a scarcity environment, to ensure microtransactions, and the repetitive gameplay means a lot of grinding.If I knew a few weeks ago what I knew now, I wouldn't have wasted my time. Avoid this game - the whole experience has degraded.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Just a note before I begin..... I have been playing this game for 4 years prior to accessing through Steam.This game is what a good Action RPG should be.  It has almost infinite replayability!Characters aka "Toons" - with 8 regular races, 4 Iconic races and 13 classes......the combinations are endless.  Each class has multiple ways to build them and with multi-classing, the tweaking never stops.  This is the biggest strength of the game in my opinion.  Add in the Epic Destinies in the later levels and customization continues to increase.  Each Resurrection adds a "Past Life" bonus which keeps you grinding for more.Content - There are tons of quests! A large amount of them are set in the Realm of Eberron.  A couple of years ago they expanded to include the Forgotten Realms (Eveningstar, Underdark, etc.).  The content includes Wilderness areas, Quests and Raids.  There are a large diversity in quests with puzzles sprinkled through out.  The difficulty is adjustable in each case.Free-to-play - When reading reviews of MMOs, this seems to be one of the biggest factors for people liking or disliking the game.  Is this game Free-to-play?  Yes, it is.  You can unlock everything in the game for free......with a good amount of grinding.   It is possible to play totally free by earning Turbine Points (TP) for completing quests.  TP is the DDO Store currency for purchasing Quest packs, cosmetics, specialty potions, etc.  Is there the opportunity to pay real money for advantages?  Yes, there are.   You can purchase TP with real money.  There are also upgrades to purchase for you character like ability and skill tomes.  So technically you can advance yourself by spending some real money, however the only way to get the great gear in the game is by grinding for it.  I played 2 years for free before finally going VIP cause I love the game so much and thought, why not....this is where I spend most of my time.Community - The community is largely made up of older people, reliving the days of PnP online in video game format.  Guilds are a good way to meet people and also gain some help.  There are opportunities for roleplaying if you find the right people.  The majority of players are good people if you are willing to learn the right way to play.... that means listening to those who know what they are doing, sticking to the plan and playing within your limits.  There are lots of resources for help onlineI have enjoyed this game for a long while and will continue to do so as long as the updates keep rolling in

content:
ry 16
												Background: D&D 3.5 DM and player of Pathfinder & 5ECombat Mechanics: Outdated, but True to Form for Dungeons and Dragons. Throw Dice at it...more dice and eventually you may find a different result.   This game like the Tabletop version is very Team oriented and much like the Tabletop experience. At Low Levels Non-Casters thrive, but at High Levels It is those with a Casting Ability that really start to take the Lead.  Some will find this system of standing in a room and holding down Left Mouse Click to kill something...Tedious...Boring...Overdramatized when it should be contact with enemy produces some kind of visible reaction from the enemy whether I miss or not...I have friends who have told me the exact thing. This Game and its mechanics are not for everyone. The Pay to Play Thing: Yes some classes are Paywalled but everything can be obtained through lots of hard work. Turbine points are given for in game progress but can also be purchased. Quest Packs are purchased and unlocked in the same way. So is the Druid Class. If you have a subscription you get all the Quest Packs and 500 Turbine Points a Month.The Pay to Win Thing: Now there is an opposite side to these Turbine Points. Not only do they unlock classes and quest packs, but they also allow you to buy ingame Convenience Items that make most of the game; Stupid Easy. Like Resurrection Cakes that let you Free Rez inside of a Module, or Items to allow you to Craft Epic Pieces, Unlimited Lockpicks, you name it.  While This is not cheating it does fulfill a model to create revenue because at the heart of any MMO is a Business and Businesses need money. I do not fault their decision to offer items like this, but it irks me sometimes at their offerings.Social Mechanics: Given the age of the game and that fact the Devs are still pushing out content (Turbine and WB are somehow still producing stuff) and the mostly active community. The Social side of DDO still has enough active guilds and Power Runners who've literally memorized the maps and quest sequences that you are bound to find a group if you look hard enough.Final Thoughts: So this game was made a while ago. By today's standards it is like World of Warcraft in that it should be scrapped and a completely new, graphically intense game of the same name needs to replace it, like yesterday. That being said I am a diehard D&D player and DM so part of me knows the frustration of trying to Disable a Trap and then roll a 1 and get completely obliterated. The other part of me knows...this type of gameplay is not a positive example for a RealTime Game like DDO.100% Watch Low and High Level Gameplay before you Get a Membership. Remember this game can be 100% Free 2 Play and you will evenentually have everything a VIP has Except for a few character Slots.

content:
, 2016
												Let me start this off by saying I've played this game for far longer than my playtime says. In fact, it was one of the first PC games I ever played, and to this day it's still one of my favorites. The world is interesting, the diversity of spells and abilities you can get is astounding, and it boasts the unique (so far as I know) feature of calculating stats and damage like an actual game of tabletop D&D. You even get a couple Dungeon Masters narrating the things you do, which I always thought was a nice touch. The sixteen-odd classes, with the ability to multiclass up to three times, and various races are each fairly intriguing, though there isn't really much you can do in the way of customization. Still, you can play as a magic robot. That's pretty cool.  The graphics are definitely showing their age, and I've run into my fair share of bugs, but it's never stopped me from having a good time. Still, the game is far from perfect, and there's a few pieces of advice I'd like to give to those interested in picking it up:1. Get some friends to play with you. This game is fine on its own, but, as with tabletop D&D, a couple friends makes it far better. The playerbase for this game is fairly small, and public groups arent' as common as they once were. If you want to co-op, chances are you'll have to seek outside help.2. Be prepared to spend money. Not on items, or gear, or things like that, but on adventure packs. This game isn't pay-to-win (how could it be, it's mostly co-op), but you do have to pay for a great deal of content. This can either be in the form of a subscription (I don't know how much that is exactly), or for adventure packs, for which you use TP, the game's freemium currency, to unlock specific quest chains. For some people, that might be an instant turn-off, but if you're like me and have trouble sticking to one game for too long, You'll probably appreciate the ability to pay as you go, rather than keep shelling out money for a game you may not be interested in at the moment. You can, as with most games, go through and unlock all of the areas for free eventually, but not unless you're willing to endure a rather long grind. I'm talking like multiple characters on multiple servers long. If you're not quite sure if you're willing to spend money on a free-to-play game, there's still enough free stuff to get a feel for if you like the game, and you can still have plenty of fun without spending a cent.Also, not sure if this is on my end or something with the game, but I've found the controls to be a tad slow and unresponsive as of late. Again, not sure if this is the game, or my computer, I've had similar problems in a few other games. To conclude, not a bad game, if you like D&D you'll probably like this. Really I'm just writing this in the hopes of keeping it alive.

												One of the best MMOs I have ever played, tons of free content and very cheap access to the rest of the game. Best played with close friends or you may end up just running through dungeons without understanding or getting a chance to admire the puzzles and traps.My favorite feature is the traps, they add lots of new mechanics, such as "do you wanna rush up those suspicious stairs, or wait for the rest of the party?"Its not perfect, it has some underused awesome systems and some overused less awesome systems, but overall i think it is awesome. If you love D&D or other tabletop games try this game immediately, im sure you will love it.EDIT: Would just like to say that if any of you have been discouraged by the "akamai netsession plague," dont be. Akamai is secure and helpful. additionally, Akamai can be easily disabled, even though it doesent even turn itself on until you use it.[/b] The people who say its a bad thing only say so because they never even bothered to learn what it does, just heard "P2P" and started screaming about how they couldent find the very obvious off button. To sum up, the game is awesome, and akamai net session poses no risk to you, all it does is speed up game updating.

content:
4, 2016
												Great MMO. Huge amount of class builds you can play. Huge amount of content to explore. If you want to grind the whole game can actually be played for free (although with just a few bucks the grind can be reduced substantially). I have played most MMOs out there but this is the one I always come back to. It has different difficulty levels on each of the dungeons which is a huge deal as it allows the game to cater to both soloers and groups and also gives the game a lot of replay value as you can always play the same content over on elite difficulty when you are higher level for often a much bigger challenge. I honestly don't know why more MMOs don't have a system like this. The only drawback I see to this game is there isn't really an open world except in the towns but honestly this is not something I miss at all.Be aware that this game was released in 2006 with graphics you'd expect from that era but the gameplay is great.

r 28, 2015
													Today was great.  I've recently come back to DDO and reactivated my VIP subscription.  After a few days I was wondering why I ever left.  I even convinced some friends to come back and enjoy the game with me.  Then I tried to purchase some turbine points and my day really great.  Opening up the store I navigated through to purchase some coins and made sure there was enough in my steam wallet to afford it.  I don't get paid till Friday, but $20 isn't bad and it's fun.  So, once I get all that set up I click to purchase the points and...error.  No problem these things happen and there's downtime soon anyway.  I'll just try again afterwards.	Downtime is over, DDO is back up and now I log in to complete my purchase and get to playing.  Error.  Ok, so maybe I just can't use the steam wallet option.  No worries, I still have $25 in that account I'll just use my card.  So I type in my card info, choose the points I want and confirm.  Error.  Can't purchase the points.  Well, now I'm annoyed, but I'm not gonna let that get in my way.  I know I can go to the site, use the store there to but a code for the coins and input that at my account page.  It's not as handy, but it'll work.	Alright, got everything set up, found the points in the store on the site, it get 50 fewer points for the same price going this route.  But at this point I just want to get things taken care of so I can get back to playing.  So I purchase the points, get the code and head over to my account page.  Seems simple, click a button input the code and here come my points.  or....Error...really?  The code isn't valid?  I bought it 5 minutes ago, I have the page still up, I've got a confirmation email.  I'll go see if perhaps it hasn't charged my card yet.	Log into the bank and....wait...overdrafted.  Hmm...oh look I was charged for both the code I bought on the site that is invalid as well as the purchase I tried to make with my card through the store that gave me an error and told me it couldn't be completed.  Ok, so now I've moved money to my steam wallet, been charged twice from my bank account, and now we can add an overdraft charge...and I still don't have my turbine points.  What a fin day of gaming, so glad this is how I spent my day off.	Do yourself a favor, stay away from trying to support this game though purchases.  If you want to play for free, it's fine.  The game play holds up well.  But until they manage to fix the terrible system they use for purchases, just stay away.

content:
, 2016
												I sank a lot more in to this game pre-Steam. DDO remains the best online MMO experience using the D&D 3rd edition ruleset, and is really a great experience, despite the fact that it show it's age. However....after it went F2P it developed increasingly elaborate monetary systems, weird crafting rules and lots of freemiu options that often felt necessary but weere very costly unless a sale was on.  If you prefer soloing or can't find players....a real problem at times....then you need to spend money on henchmen, too; the game is more balanced now than ever for solo play compared to when it started, but forget trying to go it alone without a healer, for example. DDO is not perfect, and it's aged badly, and I dislike the cash shop's excessive prices (I never bought something if it wasn't on sale as a rule) but it's still an innovative MMORPG and the best such type of game D&D has ever been translated in to.

content:
y 12, 2014
												Dungeons & Dragons Online (DDO) plays sort of like a hack-and-slash game as opposed to a more turn-based ability-heavy MMO like WoW. You control your character with WASD as per the norm, with things like blocking and rolling available. Attacking is done by holding down the left mouse button, and items, abilities, and spells are used with whatever you decide to use them with, the default being the 1-0 number keys. Everything's in real time, though some spells, abilities, and other things can take a little while to cast.Easily the strongest part of DDO (and D&D) is the character customization. Want to make a melee mage? Go for it! Want to put some different caster in your caster, so you can cast while you cast? It'll be horribly gimpy, but go for it! Aside from alignment restrictions (Barbarians and Bards can't be Lawful, Monks must be Lawful, Paladins must be Lawful Good, Druids have to be Neutral) and the fact that you can't be an evil alignment, you can do whatever you want. Generally, any character you build (unless you want a 19 Barbarian/1 Wizard to cast spells offensively or something else silly like that) can get through quests fine if you play, gear, etc. well, though some will obviously struggle, and it'll likely be very difficult to play through higher difficulties and raids with a gimpy character. You also might get weird looks in parties, and perhaps even some rejections, but making your own party for like-minded people is easy.It should be noted, though, that DDO works significantly differently than D&D, and many of the things in D&D (horseback riding, climbing, spell slots, multiple attacks per round, etc.) had to be changed. You don't have a set number of spells per day; there is instead a mana system, though the mana doesn't recharge on its own and you need to use a rest shrine (in place of resting anywhere with the possibility of being ambushed in D&D) or extremely rare potions to restore it. Casters can cast a lot more spells than in D&D, and since this was one of the main drawbacks of casters in D&D, casters tend to be more powerful than melees in DDO for large portions of the game. A lot of skills in D&D (horseback, crafting, tumbling, probably most of them, actually) had to be changed significantly or removed to fit into DDO. Numbers in generally are significantly inflated in DDO (to help fit the real-time combat so you don't just die instantly when beset by two kobolds at level 1), so don't be surprised to see people getting 1k or more HP by level 28.The game world is completely instanced; instead of running about vast landscapes (though there are some of those, I'll go over them in the next paragraph) like other MMOs, you talk to NPCs to take quests, then go to the entrance of the quests and are whisked away to wherever the quest is in an instance that is completely separate from everything else in the world and only you and your party can enter. There are currently close to 400 quests, each with their own different dungeons (though some use the same dungeon in a slightly different way), and each quest has its own objectives that you must complete in order to finish it. Most of the quests are generally fairly static (as in not random), though almost all of them have optional objectives, secret areas, and things like that. Some of them have multiple ways to reach the end and some have multiple ways to finish the quest, though for the most part there's a clearly defined objective and one or a few different ways to get there. Quests are generally available in 4 difficulties (Casual, Normal, Hard, Elite), though some aren't. Raids, for instance, don't have a Casual difficulty.Speaking of raids, there are currently 17 of them, ranging from level 6 to level 24. They're all fairly unique, though I don't have enough MMO experience to be able to compare them to other games. Some of them are rarely ran, though if you're patient or have friends/guildmates you can do any of them.There also exists things called Challenges. These are timed pseudo-quests, where you have a certain objective you must complete in order to complete the challenge, and then 5 optional objectives that give you a higher score and more rewards.There are also Explorer Areas, which are more traditional MMO areas that are open and have various things to do and explore inside them. They have XP rewards for finding certain areas, killing monsters, and killing rare monsters, and often house the entrances to quests.In terms of endgame, at this moment, there isn't much. You can True Reincarnate your character, which recreates it at a lower level with some benefits (mostly passive things, though there are active ones). If you go from level 20 back to level 1 (there's also an option to go from 28 to 20) with this, you can create a completely brand new character of any class and race, though some things (like your name) remain the same. Other than that, there are currently no raids at the level cap (though there are many below it), so I would avoid blowing through everything to get to the level cap, and instead go slowly, play all kinds of characters, and try out all the content. This will hopefully change in the near future, as the plans are to increase the level cap to 30 and stay there to develop an end-game.The community is relatively small, but still quite active. Finding groups can be a challenge, but if you create your own you'll most often at least get a few other people to come along. Even if you can't find people, soloing is very much doable for almost all of the game's content (though some will be extremely difficult or require you to use and abuse certain things to finish), even including some of the game's raids. There are also hirelings, which are NPCs you can buy and bring with you into dungeons. These are mostly useful for healing, either for yourself or to keep critical NPCs alive in quests, though the other hirelings can be useful. The game scales its difficulty based on your group size and composition, sometimes to a fault; it can sometimes be harder to do something in a group than by yourself.As far as content restrictions for free players, they're not too terrible. There are more details on this topic here: http://ddowiki.com/page/Account_comparisons. There are about 120 free quests (see here: http://ddowiki.com/page/Guide_to_Free_to_Play) and challenges can be played once per day per character for free. 4 of the game's 8 races are free to play, though one of them (Drow) is easily unlocked through play. 9 of the game's 13 classes are free as well, with 2 unlockable through play (though both of them require you to unlock/buy plenty of quests to do so). In addition, completing quests and challenges will earn you Turbine Points (TP) over time which can be used to unlock quests, classes, races, extra benefits like starting characters at level 4, or various consumable and cosmetic items. It's certainly more stingy than more recent F2P games like Path of Exile where most things or even everything is given to players for free and only cosmetics can be bought, but it's not an unreasonable system.On the whole, I'd recommend anybody at least give DDO a try (after all, it is free to play). It's certainly not for everyone, and there are issues abound, probably more than most big MMOs, but it can be a lot of fun. Don't be put off by the early questing, too; a lot of the early quests are sort of samey, featuring the same enemy and environment types. It's not until level 3-5 quests (depending on what you have available) that they start to get really interesting and unique.

content:
y 17, 2014
												Dungeons and Dragons.  Every geek and nerd (myself included) who grew up playing this on tabletob, with a bunch of frends, Mountain Dew, and Cheeto and Dorito dust encrusted hands, knew exactly how fun it was.  Now it's online.  And, better yet, IT'S FREE!The game can be played as a loner (without a group), but the higher levels you gain, the easier and more fun it is as a group.  Plus, if you enjoy the RP side (what made D&D spectacular), there are plenty of players who love to keep in character.The quests range from easy to OMFG GET ME OUT OF HERE NOW!  All are fun, and all definitely have that D&D feel.The tutorial at the beginning when you first start is helpful and recommended.The controls are also pretty user friendly.Give it a try.  If you love D&D and love online games, DDO is for you.

content:
y 1, 2016
												The mother of them all... the orginal, start and birthplace of fantasy games...Dungeons & Dragons. I remember playing this in my uncles basement, rolling die and imagining the beholders and kabolds. Now, I just click click to make a halfling rogue in 2 minutes, then makeing the same character sheet in 30. Times have changed. With free to play abilities D&D is a great game to play. Start from choosing class and race and a rather very in depth face creation hub and your off.  Start with a races human, halfling, elf, dwarf, half -elf, half -orc, warforged with the classes rogue, ranger, artificer, warlock, sorceror, paliden, fighter, barbarian, mage. With a straight foward ''quests lead to a dungeon'' and beat the dungeons with plenty of trainers and merchants around the game. It isn't very difficult to get the hang of. Like its tabletop version, you are pretty much an adventurer off to clear dungeons looking for epic loot. The quests and coupled dungeons do sometimes have a rather good sence of humor to it witch makes for a good read and laugh. The aspect of booby traps and puzzles within the game, in witch you need to use ''example'' my rogues search or disable trap abilities, was rather fun and challanging. The free to play aspect though does get limited as in higher levels you need to unlock along with dungeon/quests of that level. That makes for a lot of stuck between levels grinding for free to play players. Then just getting stuck. Is it a good run until then? YES  but, then the DLC is kinda needed. The graphics are decent with an oldschool feel to it where you can even  change the color of your dice and hubs for custimization. The music is spot on also to what you would expect of the fantasy world and areas. For the nostalgic and those that dont mind throwing some money at to progress.

content:
, 2014
												As I am new to online pc gaming (aside from Secondlife) (although not new to gaming on console) I find that I really enjoy playing DDO as I can play by myself if I choose or along with others. There are many quests and challenges to choose from or I can just wander around aimlessly and meet new friends without time limits. The game play is pretty easy to figure out, even for someone who knew absolutely nothing of how to use any of the inventory items or how to do any moves.  Within a couple hours I was running around with a few quests under my belt, some money and didnt look so noobish which was a wonderful thing. I recommend this game and I look forward to my online gaming experiences in this and other games.

content:

												I do recommend this game.  I'm a age-old D&D fan, and the flexibility of this game to make the character you want, change classes, vary weapons, etc... it's just awesome.  The dungeons and combats are much more unique than most other MMO's I've played (still not as great as solo games where you are the center of the universe)... but hey, you can play it with friends which is cool.  I was worried about the reviews, expecially the costs... but some of the posts are dated and no longer accurate.  For instance, it doesn't cost any $ to level up.  I'm now about level 8, and finally blew $35 on the game and don't really plan on spending more... that might mean I top out and don't get to the highest levels, but I don't plan on playing more than a year.  If you do go the Free to play option, I highly do NOT recommend spending any $ until you get to be level 6 or higher.

content:
ry 1, 2015
												To anybody who's played an mmorpg with an annoying game launcher that made you download even more stuff after installing the game? Yeah... you get the idea.This is a pretty well made rpg game. It's got all the aspects that an rpg should have(including F2p and a premium subcriber service). Yeah kinda peeved at that because like 75% of the content ingame is P2P and the F2P stuff get's kinda boring after you grind in them for 100000000000000+ hours. Also the launcher is a little annoying on the update system as it downloads a lot of stuff if your not on for a month or something like that.Not trying to hate on the game, it has some great things like clever item systems with multiple slot enchantments and items(doesnt sound like any other rpg game...). Fun quests(for the first time you play them). and a lot of zones(Which will take you years to reach because your too underleveled).Ok let's get specific. At the start of your game you get to create a character. First off some of the races and classes are locked because you need a premium account to use them. and the only decent looking character i could make was human(granted I always play human, but other games really built a solid image of what else should look like and DDO kinda breaks it). Second It takes forever to level up. They have a rank system where like every 5 ranks you level up, so in reality level 2 is more like level 10 and getting levels only come from a massive amount of grinding. So be warned rushers who expect to get final level in the like the first week of the game. Commit to the game and you might actually get the level 3 in a month. In the starter areas you get a lot of the story, but after, it just gets harder and harder to find all the details. As you continue there is less and less voice acting and dialogue in the quests. And the quests, Quests are dungeon based so you cant's just enter and leave them freely, so it is kinda annoying and takes a lot of your time to complete. If you do leave you get an XP penalty or something like that. And since there are so few F2p quests/dungeons you have to keep regrinding them to get XP.The combat is pretty fun, different enemy types have different resistances and slimes even break weapons faster. Item decay is something you have to worry about. you can fix them or just ignore them until your UBER GREATSWORD +7123 breaks because you were too lazy to unequip to fight a blob of jello. Combat animations were pretty cool, but got pretty silly after a while. There are always specific weapons that restricted like foreign weapons that your character needs to have a certain loadout to use and skillpoints gained on every rank to advance your character skill tree, except it get's really confusing especially if you multi-class with like 6 different skill trees and only like 2 points to spend. The abilites are easy to use if you know how to use hot-keys.Now onto the life of a subscriber. If your willing to put in the money, it can be a really fun experience, you get more Xp special areas and quests that are completely restricted to the "F2p Peaseants"(A.K.A 97% of the earth's population). you get easier access to pets, guilds, items, and cosmetic stuff. Only after you dump your life savings into the game on a monthly basis though, So go be the 3% and get the right to say that you did spend hundreds of $$$ on a fake game.So to sum it up, either be a commited and persistent person and spend the rest of your life trying to reach level 10 or go be a premium member and do a life's work in 10 minutes with the power of cash and P2W Psychology.4/10 would grind for days again

												It has its fun moments. Servers are practically dead, same bugs are around that have been around since launch (stuck on ladder, rubberbanding, failed potion usage due to lag or rubberbanding makes it go onto cooldown) their servers use dial-up which causes massive bouts of lag and more rubberbanding. Wheloon prison is a joke, great story, but to make things "difficult" they just throw hordes of enemies at you that deal massive damage and can take massive damage. Throw that in with their "too many enemies notice you so you are slowed down", attack penalties, movement penalties, etc, until you kill half of them off.While also in Wheloon prison, Shadar-kai Assassins can just spam their AoE weapon that slows, reduces attack speed, attack damage, etc, etc and stacks up to 8 times causing nothing challenging, just a pain in the ♥♥♥ of a grind fest. They made this particular expansion just to milk more money from players to use special "microstransaction" healing items and ressurrection items due to the length of the quests, no one wants to start all over in that ♥♥♥♥.In short, game can be fun, but avoid their "expansion packs" as they're just trash horde spawning messes.Stick with the core game if you plan to play. I'll continue to play, but I don't recommend this to anyone that hasn't already invested time or money.Did I mention they removed Mithril and Adamantine armors from random loot because the developers are too lazy to fix a really old issue with them?It is currently possible to get an item from random loot that has a +0 modifier to it.


Dungeons & Dragons Online - Customer Support 
A Video of Dungeons & Dragons Online®
By: Ryvucz

			They handled my ticket really fast. ~ 3 minutes. Skimmed it, made out "you should lower price of" and closed the ticket saying submit feedback. Guess I should have just kept it short. "AI does not heal 75% of the time".		


Don't offer "feedback" if you're reporting a bug.

content:
1, 2015
												Your enjoyment of the game will be entirely dependent on having a good group to work with. Unless you're able to get into the game with people who are also starting fresh (or willing to make new characters and allow you to play a role you find interesting) you will not enjoy this game at all. There is virtually nothing you can do solo in this game; you NEED to be in a party of several people to accomplish almost anything beyond level 3.Overall the game feels incredibly slow paced and is clearly outdated. Even setting aside the graphics, there are numerous bugs that feel like they just shouldn't exist in a game that has been around this long. Expect to have to restart the client at least once every couple of hours due to one issue or another. Nothing about this game flows together nicely.The amount of free content is minimal, at best; you will end up having to grind quests just to continue leveling up, and the interface is littered with frequent reminders of the things you could pay for. Unless you have a VIP subscription ($10/month) you will have only about five quests you can do per level, which will not offer you enough experience to advance, forcing you to redo them for even less XP than you earned the first time. The only workaround is being carried  through the game by someone 2-3 levels above you who can unlock quests on a higher difficulty, but then you'll be doing little more than watching them solo the dungeon. It's not fun, and you'll never catch up to a point where you can actually start having fun with them.

content:
r 30, 2016
												I've played DDO for about five years, and I still enjoy it as much as I did when I first started. I took a break for about a year and tried Neverwinter because a few friends liked it, but never really got into it. DDO has a lot more depth for a F2P MMORPG, with many classes and races, a variety of combinations to customize and multiclass characters, numerous quests both free and premium, a decently sized and fun community, and finally, what really keeps me compared to other MMORPGs... The ability to play almost entirely F2P through the whole game (the exceptions would be Menace of the Underdark and Shadowfell Conspiracy, which are both worth paying for, in my opinion, giving you new classes and access to new quests in the continent of Faerûn). Thanks to the Favor Point system, you can get Turbine Points to buy new quest packs just by playing free quests! It can get a bit grindy, yes, but that's the incentive to get you to contribute to the game with purchases. The only thing the game lacks is up to date graphics, but this game is a decade old and that has to be expected. Overall, fun game but it can be difficult to get a hang of! (Also, try the server Sarlona, and AVOID Wayfinder, if you want to play with other people)

content:
ry 23
												I bought this game when it came out and level cap was about 5 or something. I have gone back to it several times over the years, as apart from DM'd NWN stuff it is for me one of the best dungeoneering adventure game experiences on a computer.Caters to people who want to min max or casually enjoy some fun adventures without the need to devote hours to each session unless you want to. From the first little adventures to the epic stuff it is a class act with friends or solo. There have been many changes and power levels are pretty extreme as you'd expect in a game of this age, there are a lot of systems, craftings, grindy bits etc which can be intimidating but to be honest they aren't required unless after joining in on the ultimate challenge levels (I haven't), and you can find challenge in many other ways in the game - but more importantly you can find a boatload of fun adventures.It is worth your time and your money - the adventure system used with its narration was a genius touch at the time and is more satisfying than the story modes a lot of later MMOs used - adventures are group instances so may not be your thing, but if you like small co-operative adventuring it was made at a time people were mad for MMOs and it shows, and it has developed a huge amount of content of differing types. The combat and adventure skills are great too. Not flashy, but just right and allowing for a huge diversity of character builds - both effective and erm, flavour. It doesn't handhold but there are websites which can answer just about any question you could ask so not an issue and people are helpful.A great game.

content:
1, 2014
												This is mostly Reviewed as something which is on steam.If you like this game... get it outside of steam, as steam does zero support for it, even for things which involve its own end of things.for the tl;dr swaggots: As a Steam game... Won't Reccommend. why? because this is a steam review.Also, because of this, having a Steam based forum is pointless, especially seeing as how there's a recorded level of less than 200 players averaging most servers originating on steam.(This title should be removed from Steam completely)I'd probably say go with anything else outside of the DnD franchise.not many players. pretty dead. mostly solo focused. get repetitive and boring fast.also, extremely pay to win and overpriced for everything.the game is old.very. old.and glitchy, b/c its never been properly updated.in short, just a warning, you'll be wasting over 10 gigs of precious hard drive space for something you'll probably never play.This is the only time I'll say, for what it'll take to get the same gaming experience, Just go for World of Warcraft. its cheaper.seriously. its way cheaper than this Freemium scam of a game. you can't even do most of the quests without buying your way into it.the controls are very clumsy. and the graphics, even on highest settings feel wasted by the choppy gameplay and clumsy controls. again, If i were to use World of Warcraft as an example, and trust me... I hate WoW and quit it after level 80 in wotlk, i'd have to give more credit to WoW as an MMO.there's other MMO's on steam with a larger player base.another annoyance: you have to log into a server first before you can see what characters you have saved onto it. if you forget.... you'll have a fun time of starting/closing your game.actually, another game I'll actually reccomend over this is Warframe. sure, its not medevial or magical, but you'll have a better overall gaming experience with it.Edit:This game has some of the worst... and I mean WORST customer service I've ever seen in the history of all the games I've ever played and had to troubleshoot something out of.Have you ever had to deal with that one customer service rep who actually asks stupid things like "is your computer turned on? is it plugged in?" to that level of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ INEPT... wow. just wow. 3 weeks later, still e-mailing back and forth with them, including one supervisor, and two other department heads. averaging about one response a week, following up reporting two csr's not even reading their tickets.Run by WarnerBrotherGames, they also have no interest in ever linking thier purchases to Steam Wallet. they cheat steam by intentionally disabling the page for buying with steam from their in game store.have a glitch? good luck. forums are moderated by trolls who will do thier best with lines likeoh, you have to phone steam to fix your problem!(steam support has no phone number)uninstall. and please, steam, REMOVE THIS ♥♥♥♥ FROM YOUR GAMES. PLEASE. and I'm a player who owns and plays uriel's chasm.I still call this game utter. ♥♥♥♥ing. ♥♥♥♥.Also, I'd like to point out, the forums, including mods of their forums, will stalk you afterwards for even asking for assistance with issues.First time I've ever had to report a mod.http://steamcommunity.com/id/titoshivanissue still unresolved as mods rather do bans than solve technical issues and only help trolls.

I hate WoW and quit it after level 80 in wotlk, i'd have to give more credit to WoW as an MMO.there's other MMO's on steam with a larger player base.another annoyance: you have to log into a server first before you can see what characters you have saved onto it. if you forget.... you'll have a fun time of starting/closing your game.actually, another game I'll actually reccomend over this is Warframe. sure, its not medevial or magical, but you'll have a better overall gaming experience with it.Edit:This game has some of the worst... and I mean WORST customer service I've ever seen in the history of all the games I've ever played and had to troubleshoot something out of.Have you ever had to deal with that one customer service rep who actually asks stupid things like "is your computer turned on? is it plugged in?" to that level of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ INEPT... wow. just wow. 3 weeks later, still e-mailing back and forth with them, including one supervisor, and two other department heads. averaging about one response a week, following up reporting two csr's not even reading their tickets.Run by WarnerBrotherGames, they also have no interest in ever linking thier purchases to Steam Wallet. they cheat steam by intentionally disabling the page for buying with steam from their in game store.have a glitch? good luck. forums are moderated by trolls who will do thier best with lines likeoh, you have to phone steam to fix your problem!(steam support has no phone number)uninstall. and please, steam, REMOVE THIS ♥♥♥♥ FROM YOUR GAMES. PLEASE. and I'm a player who owns and plays uriel's chasm.I still call this game utter. ♥♥♥♥ing. ♥♥♥♥.Also, I'd like to point out, the forums, including mods of their forums, will stalk you afterwards for even asking for assistance with issues.First time I've ever had to report a mod.http://steamcommunity.com/id/titoshivanissue still unresolved as mods rather do bans than solve technical issues and only help trolls.
